<item>
            <title>[LANG-1384] NPE from SystemUtils.isJavaVersionAtLeast under Java 11 EA</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1384</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Calling, for example, &lt;tt&gt;SystemUtils.isJavaVersionAtLeast(JavaVersion.JAVA_1_7);&lt;/tt&gt; under the Java 11 early access release causes a NPE:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.apache.commons.lang3.SystemUtils.isJavaVersionAtLeast(SystemUtils.java:1654)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; JAVA_SPECIFICATION_VERSION_AS_ENUM.atLeast(requiredVersion);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;... which implies that &lt;tt&gt;JAVA_SPECIFICATION_VERSION_AS_ENUM&lt;/tt&gt; hasn&apos;t been resolved properly, although it looks like the code in JavaVersion intends to return &lt;tt&gt;JAVA_RECENT&lt;/tt&gt; in the case of unknown versions.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The &lt;tt&gt;java.specification.version&lt;/tt&gt; system property is &quot;11&quot; in this environment.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
$ java -version
java version &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;11-ea&quot;&lt;/span&gt; 2018-09-18
Java(TM) SE &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Runtime&lt;/span&gt; Environment 18.9 (build 11-ea+2)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11-ea+2, mixed mode)&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 11 EA&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13143515">LANG-1384</key>
            <summary>NPE from SystemUtils.isJavaVersionAtLeast under Java 11 EA</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="erans">Gilles Sadowski</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="iay">Ian Young</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 8 Mar 2018 11:18:39 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 21 Aug 2018 13:08:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 23 Mar 2018 21:02:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.8</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16391156" author="erans" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 12:13:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;it looks like the code in JavaVersion intends to return JAVA_RECENT in the case of unknown versions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Clearly, this is broken. It seems to assume that versions are always &quot;1.X&quot;.&lt;br/&gt;
 Adding a new &lt;tt&gt;enum&lt;/tt&gt; item (&lt;tt&gt;JAVA_11&lt;/tt&gt;) would work for now; but the same bug will reappear at the next unknown version.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391195" author="iay" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 12:43:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree that &#8211; particularly given the increased pace of Java releases &#8211; any real solution has to put a nail in this for good rather than just adding a new &lt;tt&gt;enum&lt;/tt&gt; reactively every few months. The &lt;tt&gt;JAVA_RECENT&lt;/tt&gt; thing seems to have been an attempt to do that, it just doesn&apos;t seem to be working.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391216" author="erans" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 12:57:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve added &lt;tt&gt;JAVA_11&lt;/tt&gt; in commit 50ce8c44e1601acffa39f5568f0fc140aade0564 (&quot;master&quot; branch).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391370" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 15:09:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=erans&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;erans&quot;&gt;Gilles Sadowski&lt;/a&gt;: Don&apos;t forget to update &lt;tt&gt;changes.xml&lt;/tt&gt; &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391371" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 15:10:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We also need to push out a 3.8 ASAP IMO so that Maven plugins like Surefire can update Commons Lang (again), to avoid this NPE.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391395" author="erans" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 15:32:13 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Don&apos;t forget to update changes.xml&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Done (I didn&apos;t know whether my changes would be sufficient to resolve this issue).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please examine the attempt to prevent the same failure for later versions (would only work if the naming scheme stays the same).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16391420" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2018 15:46:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, this will work for now, at least until Java versions go past &lt;tt&gt;&quot;99&quot;&lt;/tt&gt;. This &lt;tt&gt;SystemUtils&lt;/tt&gt; method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isJavaVersionMatch(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; version, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; versionPrefix) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (version == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; version.startsWith(versionPrefix);
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;will not do the right thing when comparing &lt;tt&gt;&quot;100&quot;&lt;/tt&gt; with &lt;tt&gt;&quot;10&quot;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gary&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1383] Illegal Reflective Access Operation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1383</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ReflectionToStringBuilder::toString prints an illegal access warning to System.err. The warning suggests to report this issue to the Apache Commons maintainers.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Boolean.TRUE is such a simple value that I don&apos;t really need ReflectionToStringBuilder. But more complex types (such as HashMap) print the same warning. I chose Boolean.TRUE in order to simplify this example.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I searched for this warning message, I found a StackOverflow answer which suggested to report it to the package maintainers (&lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46230413/jdk9-an-illegal-reflective-access-operation-has-occurred-org-python-core-pysys/46230678&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;JDK9: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred. org.python.core.PySystemState&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I also asked my own StackOverflow question about how to throw an exception for this warning (&lt;a href=&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49076972/how-can-i-throw-an-exception-for-an-illegal-reflective-access-warning&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;How can I throw an exception for an illegal reflective access warning?&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I will try to change my code to avoid this warning, but it&#160;also seems that Apache Commons should not cause the warning. Perhaps it could use different methods to get the values of the fields, or skip the private fields, or throw an exception?&#160;The warning message suggests that the Java maintainers want the Apache Commons maintainers to avoid this warning. And when they disable this illegal access in the future, then it could impact Apache Commons.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.*;&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 &lt;tt&gt;class Test {&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;public static void main(String[] args)&#160;{&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;System.out.println(ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(Boolean.TRUE));&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;}&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;}&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 &lt;tt&gt;WARNING: Illegal reflective access by org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder (&lt;a href=&quot;file:///Users/brianschack/eclipse-workspace/User%20Libraries/com&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;file:/Users/brianschack/eclipse-workspace/User%20Libraries/com&lt;/a&gt;mons-lang3-3.7/commons-lang3-3.7.jar) to field java.lang.Boolean.value&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 &lt;tt&gt;WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 &lt;tt&gt;WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13142201">LANG-1383</key>
            <summary>Illegal Reflective Access Operation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="schackbrian">Brian Schack</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 2 Mar 2018 21:22:12 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 7 Sep 2020 23:19:08 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 2 Sep 2020 19:48:17 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.7</version>
                                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                            <comment id="17190413" author="schackbrian" created="Thu, 3 Sep 2020 22:17:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=ggregory&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;ggregory&quot;&gt;Gary D. <item>
            <title>[LANG-1381] ToStringBuilder Works Inconsistently With HashMap</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1381</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the following code, why do the two lines containing `System.out.println(person);`&#160;yield different outputs? The second line indirectly calls the method `Job.toString` yielding the string `&quot;Manager&quot;`, but the first line mysteriously does not yielding `Job@28f67ac7`. The line in between `person.put(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;);` doesn&apos;t seem to me like it should make any difference.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;{{import java.util.*;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.*;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class Job extends HashMap&amp;lt;String, String&amp;gt; {&lt;br/&gt;
	@Override public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
		return &quot;Manager&quot;;
	}
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class Person extends HashMap&amp;lt;String, String&amp;gt; {&lt;br/&gt;
	Job job;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	Person() &lt;/p&gt;
{
		this.job = new Job();
	}

&lt;p&gt;	@Override public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
		return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
	}
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class Test {&lt;br/&gt;
	public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
		Person person = new Person();
		System.out.println(person);
		person.put(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;);
		System.out.println(person);
	}
&lt;p&gt;}}}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Console:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;{{Person@2b80d80f&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;job=Job@28f67ac7,threshold=0,loadFactor=0.75&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Person@2b80d80f&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;job=Manager,threshold=12,loadFactor=0.75&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;}}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13140817">LANG-1381</key>
            <summary>ToStringBuilder Works Inconsistently With HashMap</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="schackbrian">Brian Schack</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 25 Feb 2018 22:59:12 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 26 Feb 2018 16:03:33 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.7</version>
                                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16376362" author="tkruse" created="Mon, 26 Feb 2018 03:17:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Different Handling seems to come from different result of isRegistered(value) in ToStringStyle.appendInternal().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;isRegistered(value) checks for getRegistry().containsKey(value), which in case of empty HashMaps is true for any empty HashMap.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Consider also outputs for these cases:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&#160;&#160; person.put(&lt;font color=&quot;#008000&quot;&gt;&quot;a&quot;&lt;/font&gt;, &lt;font color=&quot;#008000&quot;&gt;&quot;b&quot;&lt;/font&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
&#160;&#160;&#160; person.&lt;font color=&quot;#660e7a&quot;&gt;job&lt;/font&gt;.put(&lt;font color=&quot;#008000&quot;&gt;&quot;a&quot;&lt;/font&gt;, &lt;font color=&quot;#008000&quot;&gt;&quot;b&quot;&lt;/font&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
&#160;&#160;&#160; System.&lt;font color=&quot;#660e7a&quot;&gt;out&lt;/font&gt;.println(person); // job=Job@...&lt;br/&gt;
&#160;&#160;&#160; person.clear();&lt;br/&gt;
&#160;&#160;&#160; System.&lt;font color=&quot;#660e7a&quot;&gt;out&lt;/font&gt;.println(person); // job=Manager&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At a glance, containsKey(value) might have to be replaced with identity check inside keySet()&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16377084" author="schackbrian" created="Mon, 26 Feb 2018 16:03:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Dear Mr. Kruse,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you for taking this issue seriously! Also, thank you for the explanation. I was looking at the source code, but it didn&apos;t occur to me to look at the isRegistered method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Brian Schack &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1380] FastDateParser too strict on abbreviated short month symbols</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1380</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The date format symbols of the French locale adds a . (dot) when short month names are really abbreviated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
janv.
f&#233;vr.
mars
avr.
mai
juin
juil.
ao&#251;t
sept.
oct.
nov.
d&#233;c.
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But in real world examples, the dot is frequently omitted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FastDateParser should be lenient in the case where the dot isn&apos;t there, e.g. &quot;14 avr 2014&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13140219">LANG-1380</key>
            <summary>FastDateParser too strict on abbreviated short month symbols</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="markus17">Markus Jelsma</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 22 Feb 2018 15:18:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 21 Aug 2018 13:08:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 3 Jul 2018 03:52:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.8</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>5</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16372931" author="markus17" created="Thu, 22 Feb 2018 15:20:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching a unit test proving the problem. I am not sure through there it should be fixed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16375261" author="garydgregory" created="Sat, 24 Feb 2018 02:33:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The month name Strings are returned by &lt;tt&gt;java.util.Calendar.getDisplayNames(int, int, Locale)&lt;/tt&gt;. I am not sure it would be a good idea to try to perform additional processing on those values. This is all done programatically. There might be room for adding more values based on an optional resource bundle which matches up with the French locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What do you all (the reported &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=markus17&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;markus17&quot;&gt;Markus Jelsma&lt;/a&gt; and the community) think?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16375470" author="erans" created="Sat, 24 Feb 2018 10:27:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A quick look at the code reveals all sorts of &quot;strategies&quot; (a.o. &lt;tt&gt;ABBREVIATED_YEAR_STRATEGY&lt;/tt&gt;). Hence (IIUC), the design considered not quite correct input, and could perhaps be extended with a prospective &lt;tt&gt;ABBREVIATED_MONTH_MISSING_DOT&lt;/tt&gt; &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/help_16.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16376671" author="markus17" created="Mon, 26 Feb 2018 11:01:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Gary, Gilles, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was thinking to be more lenient not only for missing dots in some month forms, but also sometimes optional or mandatory punctuation depending on Locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To give an example, we receive date formats from all over the web in the strangest forms. It is easy for us to preprocess AM and PM (stripping punctuation or whitespace), or timezone abbreviations, so it fits for the locale. But, it is not possible (or very hard) to preprocess how some locale&apos;s treat their abbreviated literals, we can&apos;t add or strip dots without knowing which month (or weekday) we are dealing with.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I did some work on FastDateParser.appendDisplayNames() to strip punctuation or append the regex question mark to punctuation, but that broke things elsewhere, so that was clearly not a good idea.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16376691" author="erans" created="Mon, 26 Feb 2018 11:22:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If the problem/issue/fix is not well-defined, you might want to post to the &quot;dev&quot; ML (using prefix &quot;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Text&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&quot; on the &quot;Subject:&quot; line).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1377] DateUtils.parseDateStrictly is not working properly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1377</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have following example to parse dates. The parsing fails in the given cases.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;removed the code from inline, since Jira is unable to handle it properly... Please check the attachment&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13134294">LANG-1377</key>
            <summary>DateUtils.parseDateStrictly is not working properly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dpalic">Darko Palic</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 28 Jan 2018 14:09:42 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:31:47 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:31:39 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.7</version>

                            <votes>0</votes>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16367466" author="orbot90" created="Fri, 16 Feb 2018 15:21:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like the examples in the test are wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The documentation of the parseDateStrictly method reads:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@throws ParseException if none of the date patterns were suitable&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;and for the date&#160;13:05:15 03.05 there is no suitable pattern in the test. The pattern&#160;&quot;hh:mm dd.MM&quot; is not suitable for the date. It should be &quot;HH:mm:ss dd.MM&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16368019" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:31:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There are two problems with the format strings:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;none of them allow for the seconds in &quot;13:05:15 03.05&quot;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the format char &apos;h&apos; expects a number from 1-12; 13 is not such a number&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1374] Parsing Json Array failed</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1374</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In ToStringStyle class, which checking if a string is a valid Json array, the boolean check was wrong.&lt;br/&gt;
original:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isJsonArray(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; valueAsString) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; valueAsString.startsWith(getArrayStart())
                    &amp;amp;&amp;amp; valueAsString.startsWith(getArrayEnd());
        }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The second expression should be valueAsString.endsWith(getArrayEnd())&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13128424">LANG-1374</key>
            <summary>Parsing Json Array failed</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="kinow">Bruno P. Kinoshita</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jaswanth">Jaswanth Bala</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 4 Jan 2018 07:13:07 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 21 Aug 2018 13:08:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 4 Jan 2018 09:18:28 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.8</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                    <timeoriginalestimate seconds="3600">1h</timeoriginalestimate>
                            <timeestimate seconds="3600">1h</timeestimate>
                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="16311058" author="kinow" created="Thu, 4 Jan 2018 09:17:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Nice catch! Thanks for reporting the issue.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixed with a small test that will force the code to go through that line. Probably coverage will increase a tiny bit.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, that test is not really important. The output generated with or without the fix is the same, from what I could tell. When that check returns - incorrectly - false, then result of toString() is appended anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But for the sake of correctness, we should fix that method and allow it to follow the correct execution logic &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks again for spotting it and for providing the fix. Feel free to submit a pull request next time if you&apos;d like your code to be included with the project. Added credits in the changes.xml, so it should appear in the website after the next release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Bruno&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1370] Fix EventCountCircuitBreaker increment batch</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1370</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Place holder for &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/309&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/309&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixes a bug where the increment count is not correctly propagated.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13120702">LANG-1370</key>
            <summary>Fix EventCountCircuitBreaker increment batch</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1368] HashCodeBuilder.append incorrect behavior with chains of nulls</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1368</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have a 7-way choice/sum/variant class, so that 6 of its 7 fields are null in each object of that class.  When using HashCodeBuilder&apos;s reflective hashCode, a 10k line java project works correctly.  When using HashCodeBuilder.append instead, sequential calls to append with a null argument cause the returned hashCode to be inconsistent with EqualsBuilder.  Correct behavior can be restored by appending a dummy non-null field initially:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	new HashCodeBuilder()&lt;br/&gt;
					.append(true) //bad return value without this dummy call&lt;br/&gt;
					.append(chc1)&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
					.append(chc7)&lt;br/&gt;
					.toHashCode();&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13117774">LANG-1368</key>
            <summary>HashCodeBuilder.append incorrect behavior with chains of nulls</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="wisnesky">Ryan Wisnesky</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 12 Nov 2017 07:58:44 +0000</created>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1364] ExceptionUtils#getRootCause(Throwable t) should return t if no lower level cause exists</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1364</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I have found the design of three root cause related methods inconsistent&lt;br/&gt;
when the input Throwable does not wrap up another Throwable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These three methods are&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   1. getRootCause(Throwable t)&lt;br/&gt;
   2. getRootCauseMessage(Throwable t)&lt;br/&gt;
   3. getRootCauseStackTrace(Throwable t)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;When the input t has no lower level cause:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the first method returns null;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the second method returns the message of t, which means the input t is&lt;br/&gt;
   considered as the root cause in this method;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the third method returns the stack trace of t, which also means this&lt;br/&gt;
   method considers t as the root cause.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Therefore, I consider the design of the first method is not consistent with&lt;br/&gt;
the second and the third.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I usually write a function myself to get the root cause of an exception;&lt;br/&gt;
and it makes much better sense to me the root cause of a Throwable is&lt;br/&gt;
itself if no more lower level cause exists.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A request: change the first method to return t itself when there is no more&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;causes&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Reported by Zheng Xie in &lt;a href=&quot;https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/commons-dev/201710.mbox/%3CCAL-LHk7jvQGM9J1SPxLB2qEsXazwwq%2BYKuv29XgWXEcccHUn0w%40mail.gmail.com%3E&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/commons-dev/201710.mbox/%3CCAL-LHk7jvQGM9J1SPxLB2qEsXazwwq%2BYKuv29XgWXEcccHUn0w%40mail.gmail.com%3E&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13112845">LANG-1364</key>
            <summary>ExceptionUtils#getRootCause(Throwable t) should return t if no lower level cause exists</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 28 Oct 2017 18:52:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 21 Aug 2018 13:08:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 11 Feb 2018 13:20:49 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.6</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.8</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1362] Fix tests DateUtilsTest for Java 9 with en_GB locale</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1362</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;On Java 9 I see DateUtilsTest fail. This is because &quot;MST7MDT&quot; zone is not formatted as &quot;MST&quot;. I&apos;m unclear as to why this is, but it is not relevant to what the test is trying to do. As such, I&apos;ve changed the zone to &quot;America/Denver&quot; and changed the format letter from &quot;z&quot; to &quot;XXX&quot; to make it more reliable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The PR also uses try-finally when setting the default time-zone to avoid pollution of global state if a test fails (the pollution here made it look like 8 test failures when there was only in fact 1).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13112579">LANG-1362</key>
            <summary>Fix tests DateUtilsTest for Java 9 with en_GB locale</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="scolebourne@joda.org">Stephen Colebourne</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 27 Oct 2017 12:02:23 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 10 Nov 2017 16:41:09 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 4 Nov 2017 15:46:50 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.7</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16222237" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 27 Oct 2017 12:04:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user jodastephen opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/304&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/304&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fix DateUtilsTest to work reliably on Java 9&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fixes failures due to MST time-zone not being formatted as &quot;MST&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
    Also sets and unsets time-zones in finally blocks&lt;br/&gt;
    to avoid pollution global state when tests fail&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    See &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1362&quot; title=&quot;Fix tests DateUtilsTest for Java 9 with en_GB locale&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1362&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1362&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;(&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1362&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1362&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/jodastephen/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/jodastephen/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; date-tests&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/304.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/304.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #304&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 0a6d43fc284b9a085d1b72ca38011187c761321e&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Stephen Colebourne &amp;lt;stephen@opengamma.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2017-10-27T11:56:28Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fix DateUtilsTest to work reliably on Java 9&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fixes failures due to MST time-zone not being formatted as &quot;MST&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
    Also sets and unsets time-zones in finally blocks&lt;br/&gt;
    to avoid pollution global state when tests fail&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1361] ExceptionUtils.getThrowableList() is using deprecated ExceptionUtils.getCause()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1361</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Though ExceptionUtils.getCause is deprecated it&apos;s used internally, for example in ExceptionUtils.getThrowables. &lt;br/&gt;
We noticed this while running performance tests where a large number of NoSuchMethod exceptions where seen since ExceptionUtils.getCause catches them repeatedly. Unless initialised carefully, creating exceptions has the overhead of filling the stack trace which was our performance concern. &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13111442">LANG-1361</key>
            <summary>ExceptionUtils.getThrowableList() is using deprecated ExceptionUtils.getCause()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1360</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Fill out methods ClassUtils to get various forms of class names in a null-safe manner:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getName(Class)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getName(Object)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getName(Class, String)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getName(Object, String)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getSimpleName(Class)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getSimpleName(Object)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getSimpleName(Class, String)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getSimpleName(Object, String)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getCanonicalName(Class)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getCanonicalName(Object)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getCanonicalName(Class, String)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;getCanonicalName(Object, String)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;

                            <comment id="16214022" author="britter" created="Sat, 21 Oct 2017 16:55:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;But in ClassUtils we already have:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; getShortClassName(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt; object, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; valueIfNull)

&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I think it should be discussed on the ML whether these methods should be deprecated and moved to ObjectUtils. I think it is okay to have them in ClassUtils, because they&apos;re dealing with classes at the end of the day and there are overloads of the same name, which take Class parameters.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[LANG-1357] org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser should use toUpperCase(Locale)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1357</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The class org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser should use &lt;tt&gt;toUpperCase(Locale)&lt;/tt&gt; internally to avoid i18n issues &lt;a href=&quot;https://garygregory.wordpress.com/2015/11/03/java-lowercase-conversion-turkey/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://garygregory.wordpress.com/2015/11/03/java-lowercase-conversion-turkey/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13108072">LANG-1357</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser should use toUpperCase(Locale)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1355] TimeZone.getTimeZone() in FastDateParser causes resource contention</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1355</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Under heavy load we are seeing contention in FastDateParser.parse() on calls to TimeZone.getTimeZone().  TimeZone.getTimeZone() is a synchronized static in the Oracle JVM.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Our proposed solution is to add a class TimeZoneCache containing a single method getTimeZone() which gets the requested time zone from a ConcurrentMap, and if not present, looks it up via TimeZone.getTimeZone() and caches it before returning it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Then replace calls to TimeZone.getTimeZone() in FastDateParser ( and whereever else) to calls to TimeZoneCache.getTimeZone().  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reason to add a separate class is because it can also be used by other applications which heavily parse or format or do other things where TimeZone is repeatedly needed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Under extreme load we have seen an 50:1 improvement in calls to FastDateParser.parse().  This saves about a ms/call in our test environment, and reduces contention.&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13105890">LANG-1355</key>
            <summary>TimeZone.getTimeZone() in FastDateParser causes resource contention</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kwboone">Keith Boone</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 28 Sep 2017 22:32:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 10 Nov 2017 16:41:08 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 10 Oct 2017 17:59:31 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.6</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.7</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>

                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="16187641" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Mon, 2 Oct 2017 03:00:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What is the format you are using?  What is the micro-benchmark code that you are running?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16188905" author="kwboone" created="Mon, 2 Oct 2017 21:44:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The format we are using most often is ISO8601, but would expect to see others based on offsets from UTC/GMT.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not using a microbenchmark framework but do have a small program that I used to test the variations below.  It spawns a hundred threads that repeatedly hit the calls in question and times the results a couple of ways.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This test creates higher load than what we would expect in normal use, but was good enough to give me an idea what we might experience with it, as I was able to create a situation showing the effects of the contention with this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: InstantType comes from &lt;a href=&quot;http://hapifhir.io&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://hapifhir.io&lt;/a&gt;, but is basically a data type that when copied, converts an Instant from a Date back to a string of the appropriate precision, and when constructed, parses the given string into a Date object (and saves the precision of the original string).  The copy operation was in the stack trace of the locked threads we saw in our performance testing beneath calls to FastDateParser.parse().  Note: Some code in hapifhir.io also pays a penalty for its own internal use of TimeZone.getTimeZone() (in calls to a Date Formatter), which is in part why I felt this needed to be an externally available API.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   Keith &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.lang.management.ManagementFactory;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.lang.management.ThreadMXBean;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.Date;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.InstantType;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class TimeZoneTester implements Runnable {&lt;br/&gt;
	private static int done = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
	private static Thread t[] = null;&lt;br/&gt;
	private static TimeZoneTester tester[] = null;&lt;br/&gt;
	private static long total;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	long timer = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
	long cpuTimer = 0;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	public static void main(String args[]) {&lt;br/&gt;
		 int numThreads = args.length &amp;gt; 0 ? Integer.parseInt(args&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;) : 4;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		 t = new Thread&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;numThreads&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
		 tester = new TimeZoneTester&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;numThreads&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		 // Warm it up&lt;br/&gt;
		 runThisStuff(numThreads);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		 // Let it rip&lt;br/&gt;
		 runThisStuff(numThreads);&lt;br/&gt;
		 long sumTimer = 0, sumCPUTimer = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
		 for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; numThreads; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			 System.out.printf(&quot;%6d\t%10d\t%10d\n&quot;, i, tester[i].timer, tester[i].cpuTimer);
			 sumTimer += tester[i].timer;
			 sumCPUTimer += tester[i].cpuTimer;
		 }
&lt;p&gt;		 System.out.printf(&quot;Total\t%10d\t%10d\n&quot;, sumTimer, sumCPUTimer);&lt;br/&gt;
		 System.out.printf(&quot;Actual\t%10d\n&quot;, total);&lt;br/&gt;
		 System.out.printf(&quot;Master\t%10d\n&quot;, currentCPUTime());&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	static void runThisStuff(int numThreads) {&lt;br/&gt;
		 done = numThreads;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		 // Create all the threads.&lt;br/&gt;
		 for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; t.length; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			 t[i] = new Thread(tester[i] = new TimeZoneTester());
			 t[i].setName(&quot;TimeZoneTester-&quot; + i);
		 }


&lt;p&gt;		 total = System.nanoTime();&lt;br/&gt;
		 for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; t.length; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			 t[i].start();
		 }
&lt;p&gt;		 while (done != 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
			try &lt;/p&gt;
{
				Thread.sleep(3000);
			}
&lt;p&gt; catch (InterruptedException e) {&lt;br/&gt;
			}&lt;br/&gt;
			System.out.printf(&quot;%d threads running\n&quot;, done);&lt;br/&gt;
		 }&lt;br/&gt;
		 total = System.nanoTime() - total;&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	public void run() {&lt;br/&gt;
		timer = System.nanoTime();&lt;br/&gt;
		InstantType i = new InstantType(new Date());&lt;br/&gt;
		for (int loop = 0; loop &amp;lt; 100000; loop++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			// Force use of parser
			i = i.copy();
		}
&lt;p&gt;		timer = System.nanoTime() - timer;&lt;br/&gt;
		cpuTimer = currentCPUTime();&lt;br/&gt;
		synchronized (TimeZoneTester.class) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			--done;
		}
&lt;p&gt;	}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	private static final ThreadMXBean THREADING = ManagementFactory.getThreadMXBean();&lt;br/&gt;
	private static final boolean IS_THREAD_CPU_SUPPORTED = THREADING.isThreadCpuTimeSupported();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	public static final long currentCPUTime() &lt;/p&gt;
{
		return IS_THREAD_CPU_SUPPORTED ? THREADING.getCurrentThreadCpuTime() : 0;
	}

&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16196329" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Sun, 8 Oct 2017 20:43:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the JDK7 implementation, synchronized method java.util.TimeZone.getTimeZone(String id) ultimately invokes sun.util.calendar.ZoneInfo.getZoneInfo(String id) which consults a ConcurrentHashMap for the zone corresponding with the id.  For &quot;custom time zone IDs&quot;, after this call is invoked and no Olson/IANA timezone is found, the custom TimeZone instance is created and returned.  This custom TimeZone instance is never cached.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suggest that the logic be to first check if the timezone id is a &quot;custom time zone IDs&quot;.  If so, create and return the custom TimeZone instance; otherwise invoke the java.util.TimeZone.getTimeZone(String id) method.  All &quot;custom time zone IDs&quot; will not hold the synchronized section open.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16196436" author="githubbot" created="Mon, 9 Oct 2017 02:19:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user chonton opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1355&quot; title=&quot;TimeZone.getTimeZone() in FastDateParser causes resource contention&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1355&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1355&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: Add FastTimeZone to decrease TimeZone.getTimezone latency&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Adding FastTimeZone to decrease latency of timezone lookups.   I&apos;ll hold this PR open for 48 hours for commons committers&apos; comments.  Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;

    +package org.apache.commons.lang3.time;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;

    +import java.util.TimeZone;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +/**&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Custom timezone that contains offset from GMT.&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * @since 3.7&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +class GmtTimeZone extends TimeZone {&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;#8212; End diff &amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="16198380" author="githubbot" created="Tue, 10 Oct 2017 09:00:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user kinow commented on a diff in the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143660909&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143660909&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;#8212; Diff: src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastTimeZone.java &amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
    @@ -0,0 +1,90 @@&lt;br/&gt;
    +/*&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more&lt;br/&gt;
    + * contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file distributed with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.&lt;br/&gt;
    + * The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0&lt;br/&gt;
    + * (the &quot;License&quot;); you may not use this file except in compliance with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + *      &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software&lt;br/&gt;
    + * distributed under the License is distributed on an &quot;AS IS&quot; BASIS,&lt;br/&gt;
    + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.&lt;br/&gt;
    + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and&lt;br/&gt;
    + * limitations under the License.&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +package org.apache.commons.lang3.time;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.TimeZone;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.regex.Matcher;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.regex.Pattern;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +/**&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Faster methods to produce custom time zones.&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * @since 3.7&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +public class FastTimeZone {&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    private static final TimeZone GREENWICH = new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get the GMT TimeZone.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @return A TimeZone with a raw offset of zero.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     */&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public static TimeZone getGmtTimeZone() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        return GREENWICH;
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get a TimeZone, looking first for GMT custom ids, then falling back to Olson ids.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * A GMT custom id has an optional prefix of GMT, followed by sign, hours digit(s), optional&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * colon(&apos;:&apos;), and optional minutes digits: &amp;lt;em&amp;gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;GMT&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; (+|-) Hours [&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;:&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Minutes]&amp;lt;/em&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    +     *&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @param id A GMT custom id or Olsen id&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @return A timezone&lt;br/&gt;
    +     */&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public static TimeZone getTimeZone(String id) {&lt;br/&gt;
    +        TimeZone tz = getGmtTimeZone(id);&lt;br/&gt;
    +        if (tz != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +            return tz;
    +        }
&lt;p&gt;    +        return TimeZone.getTimeZone(id);&lt;br/&gt;
    +    }&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    private static final Pattern GMT_PATTERN = Pattern.compile(&quot;^(?&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;?i)GMT)?(&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;+-&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;)?(\\d\\d?)?(:?(\\d&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d?))?$&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get a TimeZone with GMT offsets.  A GMT offset must be either &apos;Z&apos; or match&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * (GMT)? hh?(:?mm?)?, where h and m are digits representing hours and minutes.&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;#8212; End diff &amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Maybe instead of&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;gt; A GMT offset must be either &apos;Z&apos; or match (GMT)? hh?(:?mm?)?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    It should be&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;gt; A GMT offset must be &apos;Z&apos;, or &apos;UTC&apos;, or match (GMT)? hh?(:?mm?)?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ?&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="16198381" author="githubbot" created="Tue, 10 Oct 2017 09:00:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user kinow commented on a diff in the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143663160&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143663160&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;#8212; Diff: src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastTimeZone.java &amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
    @@ -0,0 +1,90 @@&lt;br/&gt;
    +/*&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more&lt;br/&gt;
    + * contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file distributed with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.&lt;br/&gt;
    + * The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0&lt;br/&gt;
    + * (the &quot;License&quot;); you may not use this file except in compliance with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at&lt;br/&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Do we need a private constructor to prevent instantiation of FastTimeZone? It seems to contain only static methods. Not sure if that&apos;s the intended design. But noticed it while looking at the cobertura report (which is looking great).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;p&gt;    This test is wrong. Its title states that the minutes will be out of range, but the hour is actually out of range (60). Minute is 0, but never gets checked.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

    +package org.apache.commons.lang3.time;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +import org.junit.Assert;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import org.junit.Test;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +/**&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Tests for GmtTimeZone&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +public class GmtTimeZoneTest {&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void hoursOutOfRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        new GmtTimeZone(false, 24, 0);
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void hoursInRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(23 * 60 * 60 * 1000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 23, 0).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void minutesOutOfRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 60, 0));
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void minutesInRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(59 * 60 * 1000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 59).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getOffset(234304));
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = UnsupportedOperationException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void setRawOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).setRawOffset(0);
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getRawOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getID() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+00:00&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+01:02&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 1, 2).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+11:22&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 11, 22).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT-01:02&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(true, 1, 2).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT-11:22&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(true, 11, 22).getID());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void useDaylightTime() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertFalse(new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).useDaylightTime());
    +    }&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void inDaylightTime() {    +        Assert.assertFalse(new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).useDaylightTime());    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    &amp;#8212; End diff &amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Maybe add something like&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ```&lt;br/&gt;
    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
        public void testToString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            Assert.assertEquals(&quot;[GmtTimeZone id=\&quot;GMT+23:00\&quot;,offset=82800000]&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 23, 0).toString());
        }

&lt;p&gt;        @Test&lt;br/&gt;
        public void testGetOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            Assert.assertEquals(82800000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 23, 0).getOffset(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1));
        }
&lt;p&gt;    ```&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    With these two tests we reach 100% for GmtTimeZone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="16198749" author="githubbot" created="Tue, 10 Oct 2017 14:41:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user chonton commented on a diff in the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143748869&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/296#discussion_r143748869&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;#8212; Diff: src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastTimeZone.java &amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
    @@ -0,0 +1,90 @@&lt;br/&gt;
    +/*&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more&lt;br/&gt;
    + * contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file distributed with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.&lt;br/&gt;
    + * The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0&lt;br/&gt;
    + * (the &quot;License&quot;); you may not use this file except in compliance with&lt;br/&gt;
    + * the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + *      &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software&lt;br/&gt;
    + * distributed under the License is distributed on an &quot;AS IS&quot; BASIS,&lt;br/&gt;
    + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.&lt;br/&gt;
    + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and&lt;br/&gt;
    + * limitations under the License.&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +package org.apache.commons.lang3.time;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.TimeZone;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.regex.Matcher;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import java.util.regex.Pattern;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +/**&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Faster methods to produce custom time zones.&lt;br/&gt;
    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * @since 3.7&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +public class FastTimeZone {&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    private static final TimeZone GREENWICH = new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get the GMT TimeZone.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @return A TimeZone with a raw offset of zero.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     */&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public static TimeZone getGmtTimeZone() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        return GREENWICH;
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get a TimeZone, looking first for GMT custom ids, then falling back to Olson ids.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * A GMT custom id has an optional prefix of GMT, followed by sign, hours digit(s), optional&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * colon(&apos;:&apos;), and optional minutes digits: &amp;lt;em&amp;gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;GMT&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; (+|-) Hours [&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;:&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Minutes]&amp;lt;/em&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    +     *&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @param id A GMT custom id or Olsen id&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @return A timezone&lt;br/&gt;
    +     */&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public static TimeZone getTimeZone(String id) {&lt;br/&gt;
    +        TimeZone tz = getGmtTimeZone(id);&lt;br/&gt;
    +        if (tz != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +            return tz;
    +        }
&lt;p&gt;    +        return TimeZone.getTimeZone(id);&lt;br/&gt;
    +    }&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    private static final Pattern GMT_PATTERN = Pattern.compile(&quot;^(?&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;?i)GMT)?(&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;+-&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;)?(\\d\\d?)?(:?(\\d&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d?))?$&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    /**&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * Get a TimeZone with GMT offsets.  A GMT offset must be either &apos;Z&apos; or match&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * (GMT)? hh?(:?mm?)?, where h and m are digits representing hours and minutes.&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;#8212; End diff &amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    done&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

    + *&lt;br/&gt;
    + * @since 3.7&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +class GmtTimeZone extends TimeZone {&lt;br/&gt;

    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +import org.junit.Assert;&lt;br/&gt;
    +import org.junit.Test;&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +/**&lt;br/&gt;
    + * Tests for GmtTimeZone&lt;br/&gt;
    + */&lt;br/&gt;
    +public class GmtTimeZoneTest {&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void hoursOutOfRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        new GmtTimeZone(false, 24, 0);
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void hoursInRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(23 * 60 * 60 * 1000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 23, 0).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void minutesOutOfRange() {&lt;br/&gt;
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 60, 0));&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;#8212; End diff &amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    great catch! thanks.&lt;br/&gt;
    done.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

    +public class GmtTimeZoneTest {&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;

{
    +        new GmtTimeZone(false, 24, 0);
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void hoursInRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(23 * 60 * 60 * 1000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 23, 0).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void minutesOutOfRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 60, 0));
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void minutesInRange() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(59 * 60 * 1000, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 59).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getOffset(234304));
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test(expected = UnsupportedOperationException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void setRawOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).setRawOffset(0);
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getRawOffset() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(0, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getRawOffset());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void getID() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+00:00&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+01:02&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 1, 2).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT+11:22&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(false, 11, 22).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT-01:02&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(true, 1, 2).getID());
    +        Assert.assertEquals(&quot;GMT-11:22&quot;, new GmtTimeZone(true, 11, 22).getID());
    +    }
&lt;p&gt;    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void useDaylightTime() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    +        Assert.assertFalse(new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).useDaylightTime());
    +    }&lt;br/&gt;
    +&lt;br/&gt;
    +    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    +    public void inDaylightTime() {    +        Assert.assertFalse(new GmtTimeZone(false, 0, 0).useDaylightTime());    +    }

    +     * A GMT custom id can be &apos;Z&apos;, or &apos;UTC&apos;, or has an optional prefix of GMT,&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * followed by sign, hours digit(s), optional colon(&apos;:&apos;), and optional minutes digits.&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * i.e. &amp;lt;em&amp;gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;GMT&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; (+|-) Hours [&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;:&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Minutes]&amp;lt;/em&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
          *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;* @param id A GMT custom id or Olsen id&lt;br/&gt;
    +     * @param id A GMT custom id (or Olson id
	&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;

                        <customfieldname>Docs Text</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>package org.apache.commons.lang3.time;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.TimeZone;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentMap;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
/**&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;TimeZoneCache is a thread-safe cache and retriever for TimeZone objects.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;*&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;To obtain a TimeZone, use {@link TimeZoneCache.getTimeZone(String tid).  If no instance&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* if found in the cache, an instance will be created by calling TimeZone.getTimeZone().&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* Otherwise, the instance with the matching tid will be obtained from TimeZone.getTimeZone(),&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* stored in the cache and returned.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;*&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;TimeZone.getTimeZone() is a synchronized static method, which can cause thread &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* contention under high load. If you must use a large number of time formatter or parser &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* objects, this class can be used to avoid repeated construction and synchronization &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* blocking.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;*     TimeZone tz = TimeZoneCache.getInstance(&amp;quot;UTC&amp;quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* &amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;*&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;* @see FastDateParser, FastDateFormatter&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;nbsp;*/&lt;br/&gt;
public class TimeZoneCache {&lt;br/&gt;
	/* A cache of the currently known TimeZones */&lt;br/&gt;
	private final static ConcurrentMap&amp;lt;String, TimeZone&amp;gt; timeZoneCache = new ConcurrentHashMap&amp;lt;String, TimeZone&amp;gt;(7);&lt;br/&gt;
	&lt;br/&gt;
	public static TimeZone getTimeZone(String tid) {&lt;br/&gt;
		TimeZone tz = timeZoneCache.get(tid);&lt;br/&gt;
		if (tz == null) {&lt;br/&gt;
			tz = TimeZone.getTimeZone(tid);&lt;br/&gt;
			timeZoneCache.put(tid, tz);&lt;br/&gt;
		}&lt;br/&gt;
		return tz;&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        </customfieldvalues>
