<item>
            <title>[LANG-1323] Type implementations in TypeUtils compute hash code that breaks Object.equals() with Sun&apos;s OpenJDK</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1323</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; in &lt;tt&gt;lang.reflect&lt;/tt&gt; provides convenient methods for creating objects of the interface &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt;. Those objects are defined by the following classes:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;ParameterizedTypeImpl (implements &lt;tt&gt;ParameterizedType&lt;/tt&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;WildcardTypeImpl (implements &lt;tt&gt;WildcardType&lt;/tt&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;GenericArrayTypeImpl (implements &lt;tt&gt;GenericArrayType&lt;/tt&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Similarly, there are corresponding classes, which implement the same interfaces, defined in one&apos;s particular JDK. And it&apos;s these latter classes that are instantiated when you get objects of type &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; via reflection. Let&apos;s call these the &quot;internal &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; implementations.&quot; In the case of Sun&apos;s OpenJDK, &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/jdk/file/687fd7c7986d/src/share/classes/sun/reflect/generics/reflectiveObjects&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;they are defined&lt;/a&gt; in package &lt;tt&gt;sun.reflect.generics.reflectiveObjects&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Each of the &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; classes implements &lt;tt&gt;Object.equals(Object)&lt;/tt&gt; in a general way that&apos;s compatible with the internal &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; implementations. For example, if I access a field declared with type &lt;tt&gt;Map&amp;lt;String, Integer&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt; and get its generic type, via &lt;tt&gt;Field.getGenericType()&lt;/tt&gt;, then that will be equal to the &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; object returned by:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;TypeUtils.parameterize(Map.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.class)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s what I&apos;d expect, so that&apos;s great.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; classes implement their &lt;tt&gt;Object.hashCode()&lt;/tt&gt; method in a &lt;em&gt;different&lt;/em&gt; way from the corresponding implementations in Sun OpenJDK implementations. That&apos;s not so surprising, &lt;em&gt;but it breaks the contract of &lt;tt&gt;Object.hashCode()&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/em&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;If two objects are equal according to the &lt;tt&gt;equals(Object)&lt;/tt&gt; method, then calling the &lt;tt&gt;hashCode&lt;/tt&gt; method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In other words, the two &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; objects above will both consider themselves &lt;tt&gt;equals&lt;/tt&gt; to each other, but they have different hash codes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One example of a negative consequence of this problem is a collection class that implements its equality (to other collections) by checking hash codes of its elements, e.g., Guava&apos;s immutable collections. If you have &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; objects in those collections, with &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; objects in &lt;tt&gt;c1&lt;/tt&gt; and Sun OpenJDK &lt;tt&gt;Type&lt;/tt&gt; objects in &lt;tt&gt;c2&lt;/tt&gt;, you will see that &lt;tt&gt;c1.equals(c2)&lt;/tt&gt; returns &lt;tt&gt;false&lt;/tt&gt; &amp;#8211; because their elements don&apos;t all have the same hash codes &amp;#8211; even though those elements are all considered equal.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Sun OpenJDK&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13065926">LANG-1323</key>
            <summary>Type implementations in TypeUtils compute hash code that breaks Object.equals() with Sun&apos;s OpenJDK</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="skilpat">Scott Kilpatrick</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 21 Apr 2017 15:54:37 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 24 Apr 2017 15:07:01 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.2</version>
                    <version>3.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.reflect.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15978971" author="skilpat" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 15:58:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hash code implementation comparisons:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;tt&gt;GenericArrayTypeImpl&lt;/tt&gt;: &lt;a href=&quot;https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=commons-lang.git;a=blob;f=src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/reflect/TypeUtils.java;h=8db6ca47813389708781c5117f3109865c815d2c;hb=HEAD#l134&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/a&gt; vs. &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/jdk/file/687fd7c7986d/src/share/classes/sun/reflect/generics/reflectiveObjects/GenericArrayTypeImpl.java#l89&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;OpenJDK&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;tt&gt;ParameterizedTypeImpl&lt;/tt&gt;: &lt;a href=&quot;https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=commons-lang.git;a=blob;f=src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/reflect/TypeUtils.java;h=8db6ca47813389708781c5117f3109865c815d2c;hb=HEAD#l203&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/a&gt; vs. &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/jdk/file/687fd7c7986d/src/share/classes/sun/reflect/generics/reflectiveObjects/ParameterizedTypeImpl.java#l198&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;OpenJDK&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;tt&gt;WildcardTypeImpl&lt;/tt&gt;: &lt;a href=&quot;https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=commons-lang.git;a=blob;f=src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/reflect/TypeUtils.java;h=8db6ca47813389708781c5117f3109865c815d2c;hb=HEAD#l270&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/a&gt; vs. &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/jdk/file/687fd7c7986d/src/share/classes/sun/reflect/generics/reflectiveObjects/WildcardTypeImpl.java#l224&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;OpenJDK&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="15979077" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 17:02:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Are you saying that some of the TypeUtils classes have incompatible equals() and hashCode() implementations?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If so, then that is clearly a bug. A test case would be useful.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However it is OK to provide a hashCode() implementation that is different from the &apos;standard&apos; implementation, so long as it is consistent with the equals() defintion.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, if the hashCode() implementation always returns 42.&lt;br/&gt;
It&apos;s a terrible hash, but it does not break the hash/equals contract.&lt;br/&gt;
There is no requirement for unequal objects to have different hashes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Indeed any class that assumes that equal hashCodes mean equal Objects is broken.&lt;br/&gt;
Object.hashCode() can produce equal hashCodes for unequal objects.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15979111" author="skilpat" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 17:39:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s an example in JUnit:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;OneField {
        Map&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; f;
    }

    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void test() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; NoSuchFieldException
    {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Type openJdkType = OneField.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getDeclaredField(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;f&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).getGenericType();
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Type apacheType = TypeUtils.parameterize(Map.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.class);
        Assert.assertTrue(openJdkType.equals(apacheType));
        Assert.assertTrue(apacheType.equals(openJdkType));
        Assert.assertFalse(openJdkType.hashCode() == apacheType.hashCode());

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Example with Guava&apos;s ImmutableSet, which &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; N &amp;gt; 1 uses
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// hash code &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; set equality, and Iterables.elementsEqual.
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Type other = OneField.class;
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; ImmutableSet&amp;lt;Type&amp;gt; c1 = ImmutableSet.of(openJdkType, other);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; ImmutableSet&amp;lt;Type&amp;gt; c2 = ImmutableSet.of(apacheType, other);
        Assert.assertFalse(c1.equals(c2));
        Assert.assertFalse(c2.equals(c1));
        Assert.assertTrue(c1.size() == c2.size());
        Assert.assertTrue(Iterables.elementsEqual(c1, c2));
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is this not a violation of the contract on &lt;tt&gt;Object.hashCode()&lt;/tt&gt; that I quoted above? Here are two objects that are equal according to the &lt;tt&gt;equals(Object)&lt;/tt&gt; method, but calling the &lt;tt&gt;hashCode&lt;/tt&gt; method on each of the two objects produces different integer results.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15979327" author="skilpat" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 20:28:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;: Right, the contract does not say anything about two objects that produce equal hash codes. But it does indeed say something about two objects that are equal, i.e., that they must produce the same hash code. So I&apos;m not saying that anything in &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; is inconsistent &lt;em&gt;within itself&lt;/em&gt;, but that&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ol&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the &lt;tt&gt;hashCode&lt;/tt&gt; in &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtils&lt;/tt&gt; is inconsistent with the &lt;tt&gt;hashCode&lt;/tt&gt; in the OpenJDK and&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the contract of &lt;tt&gt;Object.hashCode&lt;/tt&gt; requires that their &lt;tt&gt;hashCode&lt;/tt&gt;&apos;s be consistent since their &lt;tt&gt;equals&lt;/tt&gt; are consistent.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ol&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="15979454" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 21:49:51 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;the hashCode in TypeUtils is inconsistent with the hashCode in the OpenJDK and&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is not a requirement&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;the contract of Object.hashCode requires that their hashCode&apos;s be consistent since their equals are consistent.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Agreed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But the unit test you provided only shows that the ImmutableSet implementation of hashCode/equals is broken.&lt;br/&gt;
It does not say anything about TypeUtils.&lt;br/&gt;
Or if there is a problem with TypeUtils, this needs to be exposed by a unit test that only uses the LANG classes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15979471" author="skilpat" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 22:04:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Guava stuff was just an &lt;em&gt;additional example&lt;/em&gt; of a sneaky manifestation of the bug; it&apos;s not crucial to the bug. Sorry to have included more than necessary in that example.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For posterity, here&apos;s the example demonstrating the broken contract, without the additional broken use case: (EDIT: rewritten to clarify that an assertion fails, whereas previously it was written such that they pass)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;OneField {
        Map&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; f;
    }

    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testOfBrokenContract() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; NoSuchFieldException
    {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// An object of &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;sun.reflect.generics.reflectiveObjects.ParameterizedTypeImpl
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Type openJdkType = OneField.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getDeclaredField(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;f&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).getGenericType();

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// An object of &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.TypeUtils.ParameterizedTypeImpl
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Type apacheType = TypeUtils.parameterize(Map.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.class, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.class);

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// These two objects are equal...
&lt;/span&gt;        Assert.assertTrue(openJdkType.equals(apacheType));
        Assert.assertTrue(apacheType.equals(openJdkType));

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// ... so their hash codes should be the same. But &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; assertion fails.
&lt;/span&gt;        Assert.assertTrue(openJdkType.hashCode() == apacheType.hashCode());
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15979569" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 21 Apr 2017 23:27:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I see what you mean now. &lt;br/&gt;
It seems that there are additional equals/hashCode requirements for instances of the Type interface hierarchy which go beyond the normal equals/hashCode contract.&lt;br/&gt;
Unfortunately the requirements don&apos;t appear to be fully documented.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The ParameterizedType Javadoc specifies how the equals() method is to be implemented, but it does not say anything about the hashCode requirements.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The variables to be compared are known, so the equals() method is easily written from the Javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However there are potentially multiple ways to derive the hashCode.&lt;br/&gt;
I don&apos;t see how it&apos;s possible to code alternate implementations from the Javadoc alone.&lt;br/&gt;
So it looks to me as though the Javadoc is incomplete.&lt;br/&gt;
If the OpenJDK source were not available it would be impossible to implement an object that conforms to the ParameterizedType Javadoc and the equals/hashCode contract.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15981268" author="skilpat" created="Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:44:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yeah, that makes sense. I understand that the Java SE doesn&apos;t &amp;#8211; &lt;em&gt;but should!&lt;/em&gt; &amp;#8211; define how to implement &lt;tt&gt;Type.hashCode&lt;/tt&gt;. There seems to be a years-old JDK bug report about this exact issue: &lt;a href=&quot;https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-7082069&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-7082069&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Given the size and importance of the OpenJDK, however, would it not make sense to treat that as the canonical definition of &lt;tt&gt;Type.hashCode()&lt;/tt&gt;, and modify the Commons Lang implementations to adhere to that?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15981319" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 24 Apr 2017 15:07:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the bug URL, very useful.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are two difficulties with using the bug text as the definition:&lt;br/&gt;
1) It has not been accepted, and could be modified.&lt;br/&gt;
2) what license covers its use?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;AFAICT we cannot use the actual implementation, as that is under the GPL+Classpath exception &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1322] ToStringStyle should not use WeakHashMap as registry</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1322</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.builderToStringStyle uses a WeakHashMap as REGISTRY to detect that an object was already added to the StringBuilder to avoid recursion for cyclic object graphs. This is used by RecursiveToStringStyle.&lt;br/&gt;
In a low memory situation when the garbage collector starts, the WeakHashMap is cleared and some parts of the potentially cyclic object graph will be logged again.&lt;br/&gt;
We run in this problem, when we accidentally logged an HttpServletRequest and a HttpSession using a ReflectiontoStringBuilder   &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13065881">LANG-1322</key>
            <summary>ToStringStyle should not use WeakHashMap as registry</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="fillg1">Michael Illgner</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>

                <updated>Fri, 21 Apr 2017 13:41:14 +0000</updated>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1320] LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by UN M.49 numeric-3 area code followed by variant</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1320</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Follow up for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1312&quot; title=&quot;LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by UN M.49 numeric-3 area code&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1312&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1312&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is possible to parse &quot;en_001&quot; but not &quot;en_001_US&quot;. When parsing a string with three segments, it should be possible to use UN M.49 area codes as well.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1319] MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle StackOverflowError when object is an array </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1319</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>
&lt;p&gt;MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle style = new MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle();&lt;br/&gt;
String result = ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(new String[] &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;1&quot;,&quot;2&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, style);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.StackOverflowError&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ToStringStyle.appendStart(ToStringStyle.java:409)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ToStringBuilder.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(ToStringBuilder.java:262)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:481)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:300)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:157)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.RecursiveToStringStyle.appendDetail(RecursiveToStringStyle.java:74)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle.reflectionAppendArrayDetail(MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle.java:142)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.reflectionAppendArray(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:633)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.appendFieldsIn(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:538)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:711)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:301)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(ReflectionToStringBuilder.java:157)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.RecursiveToStringStyle.appendDetail(RecursiveToStringStyle.java:74)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle.reflectionAppendArrayDetail(MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle.java:142)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13062106">LANG-1319</key>
            <summary>MultilineRecursiveToStringStyle StackOverflowError when object is an array </summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1315] FastDateParser parse method parses without considering timezone</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1315</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Using commons-lang3 3.5&lt;br/&gt;
FastDateParser parse(String ,ParsePosition ) internally calls calendar.getTime(). This method created a new Date object which will ignore the timezone and locale. Hence will default to system TZ and locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The parse should happen with respect to the formatter&apos;s time zone but that is currently ignored&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13049236">LANG-1315</key>
            <summary>FastDateParser parse method parses without considering timezone</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sudheendra">Sudheendra</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>DateParser</label>
                            <label>FastDateParser</label>
                            <label>parse</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 8 Mar 2017 11:26:16 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 9 Mar 2017 11:43:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 9 Mar 2017 11:43:31 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>

                            <comment id="15901478" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Wed, 8 Mar 2017 16:04:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please attach a unit test that demonstrates a failure.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15902622" author="sudheendra" created="Thu, 9 Mar 2017 07:48:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Pls run the main method present in class FastDateMain&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15902921" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 9 Mar 2017 11:43:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The test case is hard to use as it&apos;s in two files buried deep in a file structure.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In future, please provide a single file which exihibts the problem.&lt;br/&gt;
Ideally as a unit test (LANG uses JUnit).&lt;/p&gt;

OS name: &quot;linux&quot;, version: &quot;4.9.12-200.fc25.x86_64&quot;, arch: &quot;amd64&quot;, family: &quot;unix&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13048369">LANG-1314</key>
            <summary>javadoc creation broken with Java 8</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15896374" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 5 Mar 2017 16:12:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user mureinik opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/252&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/252&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1314&quot; title=&quot;javadoc creation broken with Java 8&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1314&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1314&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Fix javadoc creation on with Java 8&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Java 8&apos;s javadoc seems to be stricter than Java 7&apos;s, and the current head current fails to generate javadoc (`mvn javadoc:javadoc`) with Java 8.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This PR contains a series of fixes to the various classes&apos; javadoc which are required for Java 8 (but would also improve the javadoc generated with earlier java versions) and then adds the `javadoc:javadoc` target to Travis CI so we can guarantee it won&apos;t break again.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/mureinik/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/mureinik/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; javadoc&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/252.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/252.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #252&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 972d29447d115224674154e0150d51bf9ccf6524&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Allon Mureinik &amp;lt;amureini@redhat.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2017-03-05T09:50:34Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Add @param for &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; in ArrayUtils#insert&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commit e4147a700f6c49b954a6f91dc8f2f1499777e92c&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Allon Mureinik &amp;lt;amureini@redhat.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2017-03-05T09:53:33Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fix StirngUtils &amp;lt;/p&amp;gt; tags in javadoc&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    The paragraph&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;Whitespace is defined by &lt;/p&gt;
{@link Character#isWhitespace(char)}.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;br/&gt;
    appears in several places in the javadoc (presumably, copy-pasted from&lt;br/&gt;
    the original one to the others). This is obviously a mistake, as a&lt;br/&gt;
    paragraph should start with &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;, not with &amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;br/&gt;
    This patch fixes all the occurrences of this paragraph to the proper&lt;br/&gt;
    form:&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Whitespace is defined by {@link Character#isWhitespace(char)}
&lt;p&gt;.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commit 54eff5e8a55f591c1ae3fe31fd04dce663bbe4e1&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Allon Mureinik &amp;lt;amureini@redhat.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2017-03-05T09:56:05Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Remove &amp;lt;/p&amp;gt; tag from Computable&apos;s javadoc&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    The standard javadoc doclet does not allow self closing tags (such as&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;). This patch removes such a tag from Computable&apos;s javadoc, as it&apos;s&lt;br/&gt;
    redundant anyway, as it&apos;s only used to create spaces between two&lt;br/&gt;
    existing paragraphs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commit 632431f9433ce228407218dabef7b00fa8464ef4&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Allon Mureinik &amp;lt;amureini@redhat.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2017-03-05T16:03:01Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Add javadoc creation to Travis CI&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1312] LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by UN M.49 numeric-3 area code</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1312</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;These all work:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Locale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;en&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;001&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Locale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;en&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;150&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Locale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ar&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;001&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;but these all fail with an IllegalArgumentException:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(LocaleUtils.toLocale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;en_001&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(LocaleUtils.toLocale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;en_150&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(LocaleUtils.toLocale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ar_001&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13044319">LANG-1312</key>
            <summary>LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by UN M.49 numeric-3 area code</summary>

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1312&quot; title=&quot;LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by UN M.49 numeric-3 area code&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1312&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1312&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: LocaleUtils#toLocale does not support language followed by&#8230;&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="15873893" author="githubbot" created="Mon, 20 Feb 2017 00:23:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user kinow commented on the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/239&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/239&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Yesterday learned something new about `String.format` via pull request #238, and now learning about &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;UN M.49&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_M.49&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_M.49&lt;/a&gt;). Thanks again @PascalSchumacher &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Code and test look good, checked out locally, all tests passing. +1&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15874168" author="githubbot" created="Mon, 20 Feb 2017 07:59:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1311] TypeUtils.toString() doesn&apos;t handle primitive and Object arrays correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1311</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;TypeUtils.toString() doesn&apos;t handle primitive and Object arrays correctly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Specifically, these tests will fail:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt;[]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, TypeUtils.toString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt;[].class));
assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;[]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, TypeUtils.toString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;[].class));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you declare a field with type &lt;tt&gt;List&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;[]&lt;/tt&gt;, then you can add this test:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.util.List&amp;lt;java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;[]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, TypeUtils.toString(field.getGenericType()));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This patch fixes the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; classToString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Class&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; c) {
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// begin patch
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (c.isArray()) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; toString(c.getComponentType()) + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;[]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// end patch 
&lt;/span&gt;       
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; StringBuilder buf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; StringBuilder();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13043678">LANG-1311</key>
            <summary>TypeUtils.toString() doesn&apos;t handle primitive and Object arrays correctly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="digulla">Aaron Digulla</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>

                                    <version>3.4</version>

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.util.List&amp;lt;java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;[]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, TypeUtils.toString(field.getGenericType()));&lt;/pre&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1310] MethodUtils.invokeMethod throws ArrayStoreException if using varargs arguments and smaller types than the method defines</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1310</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Since release 3.5 and due to the changes of &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1115&quot; title=&quot;Add support for varargs in ConstructorUtils, MemberUtils, and MethodUtils&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1115&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1115&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; an ArrayStoreException occurs on MethodUtils.invokeMethod if using varargs arguments and smaller types than the method defines (e.g. int vs long).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;  @Test
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testMethodUtilsInvokeMethodVarArgs () &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
    MyObject object = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; MyObject ();
    MethodUtils.invokeMethod (object, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;doSomething&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, 1);
  }

  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;MyObject {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void doSomething (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;long&lt;/span&gt;... args) {
      &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println (&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;doSomething&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
    }
  }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;throws &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.lang.ArrayStoreException
	at java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.arraycopy(Native Method)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.MethodUtils.getVarArgs(MethodUtils.java:497)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.MethodUtils.toVarArgs(MethodUtils.java:463)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.MethodUtils.invokeMethod(MethodUtils.java:234)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.MethodUtils.invokeMethod(MethodUtils.java:270)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.MethodUtils.invokeMethod(MethodUtils.java:147)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In 3.4. a NoSuchMethodException had been thrown, but in 3.5 the code now finds the matching method but fails then with above exception.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13039464">LANG-1310</key>
            <summary>MethodUtils.invokeMethod throws ArrayStoreException if using varargs arguments and smaller types than the method defines</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="eicki">Eickvonder</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 1 Feb 2017 13:36:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Jun 2017 12:04:50 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 19 Mar 2017 16:17:35 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.5</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.6</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.reflect.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15906584" author="drajakumar" created="Sun, 12 Mar 2017 16:35:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The issue is because in the below line from method getVarArgs (in MethodUtils class)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;System.arraycopy(args, methodParameterTypes.length - 1, varArgsArray, 0, varArgLength);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for the example shared in the ticket &lt;br/&gt;
args is of type java.lang.Integer and varArgsArray is of type java.lang.Long&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and hence the exception ArrayStoreException is thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reason for args to be of type java.lang.Integer is because at the top of the execution of invokeMethod, in the below line, when args is passed (which is nothing but 1 a primitive type) is considered as  java.lang.Integer and not primitive type int&lt;br/&gt;
final Class&amp;lt;?&amp;gt;[] parameterTypes = ClassUtils.toClass(args);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;parameterTypes in this case is java.lang.Integer and not primitive type int.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is the inference made on this so far.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Working on it further, will update the ticket with more details/fix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15907842" author="githubbot" created="Mon, 13 Mar 2017 16:52:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user drajakumar opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1310&quot; title=&quot;MethodUtils.invokeMethod throws ArrayStoreException if using varargs arguments and smaller types than the method defines&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1310&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1310&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/drajakumar/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/drajakumar/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; master&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #256&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15924195" author="githubbot" created="Tue, 14 Mar 2017 13:35:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user coveralls commented on the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/256&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

                     &quot;a&quot;, &quot;b&quot;, &quot;c&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
             assertEquals(&quot;foo(String...)&quot;, MethodUtils.invokeMethod(testBean, &quot;foo&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;

    +            MethodUtils.invokeMethod(testBean, &quot;foo&quot;,

    @Test(expected = NoSuchMethodException.class)&lt;br/&gt;
    public void methodName(){&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;p&gt;    I find that the expect exception works well only with very short tests.  In this case if any of the earlier method calls throws the NoSuchMethodException the test will not fail.  In my opinion the current construct is the better one.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1305] FastDateFormat in 3.5 failed test of 3.3.2 while parsing 2014-12-15T19:50:00-05:00</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1305</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&apos;T&apos;HH:mm:ssZ&quot;, TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;GMT-05:00&quot;)).parse(&quot;2014-12-15T19:50:00-05:00&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This will work on 3.3.2, however, when I upgraded to 3.5 it failed like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.text.ParseException: Unparseable date: 2014-12-15T19:50:00-05:00&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This made me suprized and I have to carefully check my unit tests to see whether upgrade to 3.5 is reliable.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows7, JDK1.8U112&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13031028">LANG-1305</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat in 3.5 failed test of 3.3.2 while parsing 2014-12-15T19:50:00-05:00</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nathanael4ever@gmail.com">Nathanael Yang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 29 Dec 2016 07:44:56 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 20 Feb 2017 03:24:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 20 Feb 2017 03:24:52 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15844086" author="ayush chaubey" created="Sat, 28 Jan 2017 15:06:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;According to the API the date pattern in FastDateFormat follows SimpleDateFormat.&lt;br/&gt;
In the issue above the specified date is -&lt;br/&gt;
2014-12-15T19:50:00-05:00&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;whereas it should be -&lt;br/&gt;
2014-12-15T19:50:00-0500&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reason is that letter &apos;Z&apos; is used to represent RFC 822 time zone and its format is like - 0500&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15873988" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Mon, 20 Feb 2017 03:24:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If you need the colon in the input, then use the &apos;X&apos; format specifier.  Without the colon, use the &apos;z&apos; or &apos;Z&apos; format specifier.  The fact that a prior version of FastDateFormat would accept the colon was a bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1302] java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException resulting in WordUtils.wrap</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1302</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Commons-lang3:3.5&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Issue code:&lt;br/&gt;
String appName = &quot;Google Play Store&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
appName = WordUtils.wrap(appName, appName.length()/2);&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(appName);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Resulting exception:&lt;br/&gt;
Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -3&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.String.substring(String.java:1967)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:328)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:176)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:100)&lt;br/&gt;
	at removedups.Main2.main(Main2.java:32)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This exception does not occur in commons-lang3:3.4 though&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Mac, Android, Linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13030113">LANG-1302</key>
            <summary>java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException resulting in WordUtils.wrap</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1296] ArrayUtils.addAll() has unsafe use of varargs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1296</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;ArrayUtils.addAll()&lt;/tt&gt; is marked as &lt;tt&gt;@SafeVarargs&lt;/tt&gt;, but I suspect the use of the varargs is unsafe.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;An example, drawn heavily from &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/a/14252221/474189&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this StackOverflow answer&lt;/a&gt;, demonstrates this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] arrayOfTwo(T a, T b) {
   &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; ArrayUtils.addAll(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, a, b);
}

@Test
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testBadVarArgs() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
   @SuppressWarnings(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;unused&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Need to assign to trigger exception
&lt;/span&gt;   &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] result = arrayOfTwo(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;foo&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;bar&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;the above code throws an exception: &lt;tt&gt;java.lang.ClassCastException: [Ljava.lang.Object; cannot be cast to [Ljava.lang.String;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here, the &lt;tt&gt;null&lt;/tt&gt; input array causes the method to return a clone of the vararg array. This is what triggers the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I faced a similar issue when adding the &lt;tt&gt;ArrayUtils.insert(...)&lt;/tt&gt; methods and I solved it by returning &lt;tt&gt;null&lt;/tt&gt; if the input array is &lt;tt&gt;null&lt;/tt&gt;. We can&apos;t do this here without breaking behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13027464">LANG-1296</key>
            <summary>ArrayUtils.addAll() has unsafe use of varargs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 12 Dec 2016 14:33:46 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 8 Sep 2017 17:10:52 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15743411" author="pascalschumacher" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 22:48:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A version of commons-lang containing this method with the @SafeVarargs annotation has not been released yet, so the annotation can just be removed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15832089" author="pascalschumacher" created="Fri, 20 Jan 2017 16:50:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have just removed the SafeVarargs annotation from the method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1295] ArrayUtils.toArray(T... items) has unsafe use of varargs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1295</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;ArrayUtils.toArray(T... items)&lt;/tt&gt; is marked as &lt;tt&gt;@SafeVarargs&lt;/tt&gt;, but I suspect the use of the varargs is unsafe.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;An example, drawn heavily from &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/a/14252221/474189&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this StackOverflow answer&lt;/a&gt;, demonstrates this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] arrayOfTwo(T a, T b) {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; ArrayUtils.toArray(a, b);
}

@Test
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testBadVarArgs() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
    @SuppressWarnings(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;unused&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Need to assign to trigger exception
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] result = arrayOfTwo(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;foo&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;bar&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;the above code throws an exception: &lt;tt&gt;java.lang.ClassCastException: [Ljava.lang.Object; cannot be cast to [Ljava.lang.String;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13027421">LANG-1295</key>
            <summary>ArrayUtils.toArray(T... items) has unsafe use of varargs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 12 Dec 2016 11:09:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 8 Sep 2017 17:10:56 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15742049" author="dmjones500" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 14:29:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, this method seems to do exactly what you&apos;re not supposed to do with varargs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We may have to deprecate this and warn people off using it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m going to create another issue for the &lt;tt&gt;addAll&lt;/tt&gt; method, since the solution (and discussion thereof) is likely to be different.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15743414" author="pascalschumacher" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 22:48:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A version of commons-lang containing this method with the @SafeVarargs annotation has not been released yet, so the annotation can just be removed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15747364" author="dmjones500" created="Wed, 14 Dec 2016 05:48:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed, but the bigger question on this issue and &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1296&quot; title=&quot;ArrayUtils.addAll() has unsafe use of varargs&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1296&quot;&gt;LANG-1296&lt;/a&gt; is can we fix the underlying problem and, if not, how best to cope with that.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15758385" author="dmjones500" created="Sun, 18 Dec 2016 07:20:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The only solution I can think of here is to deprecate the original method and instead offer:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    @SafeVarargs
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] toArrayOf(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Class&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;T&amp;gt; clazz, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; T... items) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (items == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
        
        @SuppressWarnings(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;unchecked&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)
        T[] result = (T[]) Array.newInstance(clazz, items.length);
        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.arraycopy(items, 0, result, 0, items.length);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; result;
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe this new method is safe, since it only relies on the items being of type &lt;tt&gt;T&lt;/tt&gt;, but doesn&apos;t care whether &lt;tt&gt;items&lt;/tt&gt; is a &lt;tt&gt;T[]&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thoughts and comments on this issue very welcome!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15832097" author="pascalschumacher" created="Fri, 20 Jan 2017 16:53:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As I first step I have just removed the SafeVarargs annotation from the method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16023556" author="joehni" created="Wed, 24 May 2017 19:54:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am definitely -1 for deprecation. We have a lot of unit tests for this method, that demonstrate, what actually works (incl. indirect generic calls). In the case above, you get a compiler warning for the return value of the method arrayOfTwo if the @SafeVarargs is missing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1292] WordUtils.wrap throws StringIndexOutOfBoundsException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1292</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>
&lt;p&gt;Running following line of code results in StringIndexOutOfBoundsException (in 3.5 release)&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;WordUtils.wrap(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa&quot;&lt;/span&gt;,70);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; index out of range: -1

	at java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.substring(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.java:1967)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:328)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:176)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.WordUtils.wrap(WordUtils.java:100)
	at pl.netpr.commons.string.TextToolsTest.testWrap(TextToolsTest.java:245)
	
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It worked fine with 3.4 releae. &lt;/p&gt;




</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1287] RandomStringUtils#random can enter infinite loop if end parameter is to small</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1287</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;I faced that the random method can cause an infinite loop. It can be caused if the end parameter is too low for generating either numbers (&amp;lt; 48) or letters (&amp;lt;65). I added some exception tests to make the cases clear. Basically, if we call the random function with for example numbers = true &amp;amp;&amp;amp; end &amp;lt; 48 the validation for Character.isDigit(ch) will fail and we increment count count++.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Ivan Morozov &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/211&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/211&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13021776">LANG-1287</key>
            <summary>RandomStringUtils#random can enter infinite loop if end parameter is to small</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 18 Nov 2016 15:41:33 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Jun 2017 12:04:53 +0000</updated>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1286] RandomStringUtils random method can overflow and return characters outside of specified range</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1286</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;RandomStringUtils.random()&lt;/tt&gt; can overflow and return characters that are outside the range specified by the &lt;tt&gt;start&lt;/tt&gt; and &lt;tt&gt;end&lt;/tt&gt; parameters. This is because it casts a random integer in the range &lt;tt&gt;[start,end)&lt;/tt&gt; to a character, without checking if this will overflow.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example failing test case:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;@Test
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testCharOverflow() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; start = 65535;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; end = &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.MAX_VALUE;
    
    @SuppressWarnings(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;serial&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)
    Random fixedRandom = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Random() {
        @Override
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; nextInt(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; n) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Prevents selection of &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;start&apos;&lt;/span&gt; as the character
&lt;/span&gt;            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; 1;
        }
    };
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; result = RandomStringUtils.random(1, start, end, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, fixedRandom);
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;char&lt;/span&gt; c = result.charAt(0);
    assertTrue(c &amp;gt;= start &amp;amp;&amp;amp; c &amp;lt; end);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13021590">LANG-1286</key>
            <summary>RandomStringUtils random method can overflow and return characters outside of specified range</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 17 Nov 2016 21:00:37 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 14 Dec 2016 06:34:34 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 14 Dec 2016 06:34:34 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.5</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.6</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15747451" author="dmjones500" created="Wed, 14 Dec 2016 06:34:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in commit 7f7fa03ea.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The class needs an overhaul to make better use of the code point methods in &lt;tt&gt;Character&lt;/tt&gt;. I&apos;ll work on that in future commits.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Repository: commons-lang&lt;br/&gt;
Updated Branches:&lt;br/&gt;
 refs/heads/master 35c27d025 -&amp;gt; 7f7fa03ea&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1286&quot; title=&quot;RandomStringUtils random method can overflow and return characters outside of specified range&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1286&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1286&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: RandomStringUtils random method can overflow...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Project: &lt;a href=&quot;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/repo&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/repo&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Commit: &lt;a href=&quot;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/commit/f643b4fa&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/commit/f643b4fa&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Tree: &lt;a href=&quot;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/tree/f643b4fa&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/tree/f643b4fa&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Diff: &lt;a href=&quot;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/diff/f643b4fa&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/commons-lang/diff/f643b4fa&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
