<item>
            <title>[LANG-1210] StringUtils#startsWithAny has error in Javadoc</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1210</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;startsWithAny says in its javaDoc: &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;/** 
@&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; {@code &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;} &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; the CharSequence starts with any of the the prefixes, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; insensitive, or both {@code &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;} 
**/
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;but uses startsWith(final CharSequence str, final CharSequence prefix) which is &lt;b&gt;case sensitive&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either the JavaDoc of startsWithAny method should be changed or startsWithIgnoreCase() or startsWith(CharSequence,CharSequence,boolean) should be used.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12945473">LANG-1210</key>
            <summary>StringUtils#startsWithAny has error in Javadoc</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1207] StringUtils.equals with CharSequence - IndexOutOfBoundsException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1207</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Good day,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is my first report here, so I&apos;m really sorry if I did not fill in the form right .&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I just ran into a bug with the method &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;b&gt;public static boolean equals(final CharSequence cs1, final CharSequence cs2)&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If one of the object is not the String object, the method use the CharSequenceUtils to check the equality. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is that using Math.max(cs1.length(), cs2.length()) give the max length of the 2 objects. Then 1 of the object throw &lt;b&gt;IndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think it will be better to check the size before using CharSequenceUtils as the method equalsIgnoreCase.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe this code could correct the bug :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if (cs1 == cs2) {&lt;br/&gt;
    return true;&lt;br/&gt;
} else if (cs1 == null || cs2 == null) {&lt;br/&gt;
    return false;&lt;br/&gt;
} else if (cs1.length() != cs2.length()) {&lt;br/&gt;
    return false;&lt;br/&gt;
} else if (cs1 instanceof String &amp;amp;&amp;amp; cs2 instanceof String) {&lt;br/&gt;
    return cs1.equals(cs2);&lt;br/&gt;
} else {&lt;br/&gt;
    return CharSequenceUtils.regionMatches(cs1, false, 0, cs2, 0, cs1.length());&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Kind regards,&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12942969">LANG-1207</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.equals with CharSequence - IndexOutOfBoundsException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="yogo95">NEGRO Eric</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 24 Feb 2016 14:23:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 24 Feb 2016 15:04:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 24 Feb 2016 14:45:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15163110" author="rikles" created="Wed, 24 Feb 2016 14:45:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Eric,&lt;br/&gt;
Thank you for your interest in Commons-Lang and for this bug report.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This issue have already been fixed in the current development version and will be available in the next release of Commons-Lang.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15163151" author="yogo95" created="Wed, 24 Feb 2016 15:04:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Loic,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you for your fast reply. I&apos;ll wait the new release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>
                            <issuelinktype id="12310000">
                    <name>Duplicate</name>
                                            <outwardlinks description="duplicates">
                                        <issuelink>
            <issuekey id="12853971">LANG-1162</issuekey>
        </issuelink>
                            </outwardlinks>
                                                        </issuelinktype>
                    </issuelinks>
                <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1205] NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with NumberUtils.isNumber()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1205</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The &lt;tt&gt;NumberUtils.createNumber()&lt;/tt&gt; method fails to check for multiple trailing characters, and as a result, it returns a value even though &lt;tt&gt;NumberUtils.isNumber()&lt;/tt&gt; indicates that it should not.  For example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isNumber = NumberUtils.isNumber(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;81.5514DD&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);   &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// returns &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Number&lt;/span&gt; numValue = NumberUtils.createNumber(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;81.5514DD&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);  &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// returns a &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Double&lt;/span&gt; value, 81.5514&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would expect the &lt;tt&gt;createNumber()&lt;/tt&gt; method to throw a &lt;tt&gt;NumberFormatException&lt;/tt&gt; in this case.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12941448">LANG-1205</key>
            <summary>NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with NumberUtils.isNumber()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dbrown_bps">Daniel Brown</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 23 Feb 2016 16:40:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:00:39 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 24 Apr 2016 03:37:53 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.math.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                            <comment id="15163855" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 24 Feb 2016 21:45:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patches with unit tests are welcome! &lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1205&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with NumberUtils.isNumber()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1205&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1205&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with Nu&#8230;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/130.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/130.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #130&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 568b1ded1bb6c11bfcf4f86767b52fb4ee5e125b&lt;br/&gt;
Author: patrick.brose &amp;lt;patrick.brose@mailbox.tu-berlin.de&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2016-03-17T14:23:57Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1205&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with NumberUtils.isNumber()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1205&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1205&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; NumberUtils.createNumber() behaves inconsistently with NumberUtils.isNumber()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15199624" author="pbrose" created="Thu, 17 Mar 2016 14:34:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This bug only worked with doubles or floats that have two trailing characters. The reason is that one trailing character was stripped off the source string and used for identifying the data type. This left one trailing character in the substring which was used in Double.valueOf(substring) or Float.valueOf(substring). Instead, one should use Double.valueOf(source string) or Float.valueOf(source string), which throws the expected NumberFormatException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FYI: Long does not have the same problem because here Long.decode() is used instead of Long.valueOf().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Pull request:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/130&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/130&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15255469" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Sun, 24 Apr 2016 03:37:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;commit b877fb9abef4a19eec9cc7329acbd433648b8f7b&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1203] Separated annotations HashCodeExclude and EqualsExclude break the general contract for the hashCode method in java.lang.Object</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1203</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Since version 3.5-SNAPSHOT the annotations HashCodeExclude and EqualsExclude exist in component &lt;a href=&quot;https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=commons-lang.git;a=tree;f=src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder;hb=HEAD&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;lang.builder.*&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A separated handling of both annotations breaks the general contract for the hashCode method in java.lang.Object (&quot;If two objects are equal according to the equals(Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Rather there should exist only one exclude annotation dedicated to both methods, like &apos;EqualsAndHashCodeExclude&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12935948">LANG-1203</key>
            <summary>Separated annotations HashCodeExclude and EqualsExclude break the general contract for the hashCode method in java.lang.Object</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="wildhai">Frank Forster</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 2 Feb 2016 12:27:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 4 Dec 2016 16:20:57 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15720199" author="dmjones500" created="Sun, 4 Dec 2016 16:20:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There may be some reasons why excluding a value from a hash code makes sense. See &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4748211/java-equal-and-hashcode-based-on-different-fields&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this StackOverflow question&lt;/a&gt; for some discussion on that topic.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think there&apos;s an argument for having two annotations:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;HashCodeExclude&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;EqualsAndHashCodeExclude&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I can&apos;t see how you can exclude something from equals and not from hash code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1202] parseDateStrictly does&apos;t pass specified locale</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1202</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-799&quot; title=&quot;DateUtils#parseDate uses default locale; add Locale support&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-799&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-799&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; added support for specifying a locale, but parseDateStrictly() doesn&apos;t pass it to the final parseDateWithLeniency() method.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12932186">LANG-1202</key>
            <summary>parseDateStrictly does&apos;t pass specified locale</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="markus17">Markus Jelsma</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 18 Jan 2016 16:34:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 15:24:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 26 Jul 2016 03:18:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15105507" author="markus17" created="Mon, 18 Jan 2016 16:47:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch! For some reason it also contains a lot of files i didn&apos;t modify. I&apos;m new to git but did a git clone, only modified DateUtils and the test. I don&apos;t know why it thinks i modified:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;        modified:   src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/ArrayUtils.java
        modified:   src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/DateUtils.java
        modified:   src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/ReflectionToStringBuilderConcurrencyTest.java
        modified:   src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/ReflectionToStringBuilderMutateInspectConcurrencyTest.java

                            <comment id="15105510" author="markus17" created="Mon, 18 Jan 2016 16:49:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Anyway, these are the changes due to lack of producing a normal patch file&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testLANG799whichDidNotWork() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ParseException {
        DateUtils.parseDateStrictly(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;09 abril 2008 23:55:38 GMT&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Locale(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;es&quot;&lt;/span&gt;), &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[]{&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss zzz&quot;&lt;/span&gt;});
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    /**
     * &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Parses a string representing a date by trying a variety of different parsers,
     * using the &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;default&lt;/span&gt; date format symbols &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; the given locale..&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;
     * 
     * &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;The parse will &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; each parse pattern in turn.
     * A parse is only deemed successful &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; it parses the whole of the input string.
     * If no parse patterns match, a ParseException is thrown.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;
     * The parser parses strictly - it does not allow &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; dates such as &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;February 942, 1996&quot;&lt;/span&gt;. 
     * 
     * @param str  the date to parse, not &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
     * @param locale the locale whose date format symbols should be used. If &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;,
     * the system locale is used (as per {@link #parseDateStrictly(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;...)}).
     * @param parsePatterns  the date format patterns to use, see SimpleDateFormat, not &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; the parsed date
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; the date string or pattern array is &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ParseException &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; none of the date patterns were suitable
     * @since 3.2
     */
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; Date parseDateStrictly(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; str, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Locale locale, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;... parsePatterns) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ParseException {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; parseDateWithLeniency(str, locale, parsePatterns, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;);
    }  
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1199] Fix implementation of StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1199</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The current implementation of StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance() does not compute the correct result in some cases. See #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-944&quot; title=&quot;Add the Jaro-Winkler string distance algorithm to StringUtils &quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-944&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-944&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; for the initial code contribution.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance(&quot;Haus Ingeborg&quot;, &quot;Ingeborg Esser&quot;) == 0.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is due to the incorrect computation of common characters, which causes the algorithm to exit prematurely.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In contrast, the implementation in Lucene gives ~0.63, which is about right.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    JaroWinklerDistance d = new JaroWinklerDistance();&lt;br/&gt;
    getDistance(&quot;Haus Ingeborg&quot;, &quot;Ingeborg Esser&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://lucene.apache.org/core/3_0_3/api/contrib-spellchecker/org/apache/lucene/search/spell/JaroWinklerDistance.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://lucene.apache.org/core/3_0_3/api/contrib-spellchecker/org/apache/lucene/search/spell/JaroWinklerDistance.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12929858">LANG-1199</key>
            <summary>Fix implementation of StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="msteiger">M. Steiger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 13 Jan 2016 15:54:32 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 3 Apr 2017 12:45:16 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 5 Jun 2016 15:40:28 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>5</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15294010" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 20 May 2016 19:20:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user PascalSchumacher opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/148&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/148&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1199&quot; title=&quot;Fix implementation of StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1199&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1199&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: Incorrect implementation of StringUtils#getJaroWinklerDist&#8230;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &#8230;ance()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    replace current implementation with Jaro-Winkler distance implementation of Apache Lucene&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1199&quot; title=&quot;Fix implementation of StringUtils.getJaroWinklerDistance()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1199&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1199&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: Incorrect implementation of StringUtils#getJaroWinklerDistance()&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1194] Travis-ci build fails occasionally with &quot;Killed&quot; message</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1194</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;travis-ci build occasionally fails with a &quot;Killed&quot; message in the log.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The killed test is usually one of:&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.StringEscapeUtilsTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.HashSetvBitSetTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ToStringStyleConcurrencyTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat_ParserTest&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If travis build is restarted, the build will eventually pass.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The build with same code in other environments does not occur on any local environment.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12924315">LANG-1194</key>
            <summary>Travis-ci build fails occasionally with &quot;Killed&quot; message</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                            <comment id="15071666" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Fri, 25 Dec 2015 16:55:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;travis-ci documentation mentions that build will be killed if more than 10 minutes passes between log messages or if total memory of VM exceeds 3G.  Since entire build takes less than 8 minutes, I&apos;ve investigated the memory concern.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15071668" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Fri, 25 Dec 2015 17:00:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Dumping the memory usage using the MemoryMXBean:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;heap init:493,929,088 commited:2,930,245,632 max:7,025,983,488 used:2,307,514,072&lt;br/&gt;
non-heap init:24,576,000 commited:25,034,752 max:224,395,264 used:17,364,104&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The committed heap memory is close to 3G limit.  Travis 3G limit is probably total footprint.  We&apos;ll need to allow for the maven footprint and jvm non-heap memory.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15071722" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Fri, 25 Dec 2015 20:41:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;limit heap memory to prevent from bumping into Travis CI 3G memory limit.&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1193] ordinalIndexOf(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, 1) gives incorrect answer of -1 (correct answer should be 0)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1193</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In Apache Commons Lang 3.4, StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, 1) gives incorrect answer of -1 (correct answer should be 0)&#12290;but StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;a&quot;, 1) gives correct answer of 0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Based on the above mentioned observation, the bug occurrs if the searchStr is of length &amp;gt; 1, and locates at the index 0 of the str.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In Apache Commons Lang 2.6, this bug is not observed.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;OS X Yosemite 10.10.5. Maven project.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12921028">LANG-1193</key>
            <summary>ordinalIndexOf(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, 1) gives incorrect answer of -1 (correct answer should be 0)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="qin.li@everydayratings.com">Qin Li</reporter>

                    </labels>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1192] FastDateFormat does not support the week-year component (uppercase &apos;Y&apos;)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1192</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The Java SimpleDateFormat supports two year-components, &apos;y&apos; for normal year and &apos;Y&apos; for &apos;Week year&apos;, see &lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However when we try to use FastDateFormat to parse a format which uses the week-year, it fails with an exception&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Illegal pattern component: YYYY
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDatePrinter.parsePattern(FastDatePrinter.java:282)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDatePrinter.init(FastDatePrinter.java:149)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDatePrinter.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDatePrinter.java:142)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateFormat.java:384)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateFormat.java:369)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat$1.createInstance(FastDateFormat.java:91)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat$1.createInstance(FastDateFormat.java:88)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FormatCache.getInstance(FormatCache.java:82)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.getInstance(FastDateFormat.java:119)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Simple unit test to reproduce this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testCommonsLang() {
    	Date date = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Date();

    	Format dateFormat = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; SimpleDateFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;YYYY&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		assertNotNull(dateFormat.format(date));

        dateFormat = FastDateFormat.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;YYYY&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		assertNotNull(dateFormat.format(date));
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12920697">LANG-1192</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat does not support the week-year component (uppercase &apos;Y&apos;)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dominik.stadler@gmx.at">Dominik Stadler</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>easytest</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 10 Dec 2015 08:16:10 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 25 Dec 2015 20:50:17 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15053127" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 18:11:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Comparison with &lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html&lt;/a&gt; shows that Java 7 added &apos;X&apos;, &apos;Y&apos; and &apos;u&apos;.&lt;br/&gt;
Only &apos;X&apos; has been implemented so far.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15054032" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Sat, 12 Dec 2015 04:39:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&apos;u&apos; is straight forward.  implemented with commit 2ebf9a21d2dc99ab2f434111cac9dcd6da99d574&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15054495" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Sat, 12 Dec 2015 17:50:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;To make &apos;Y&apos; useful, the internal Calendar must be exposed to allow the minimalDaysInFirstWeek and firstDayOfWeek to be set.  Unfortunately, this has side-effect of limiting thread safety.  To obtain ISO8601 behavior, we could set internal calendar instances to have minimalDaysInFirstWeek=4 and firstDayOfWeek=MONDAY.  Or, we could provide a way for client to provide Calendar instance (also useful for  &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-933&quot; title=&quot;Request to support custom DateFormatSymbols in FastDateFormat&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-933&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-933&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15062155" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Thu, 17 Dec 2015 14:58:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;commit 2fa0b168d62a07365b2787d0ed97fa1c2cfb673b reverted while investigating travis failures (&lt;a href=&quot;https://travis-ci.org/apache/commons-lang/builds/96652842&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://travis-ci.org/apache/commons-lang/builds/96652842&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15071229" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Thu, 24 Dec 2015 20:30:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe a travis-ci issue.  Did not reproduce on any local environment.  Logs from travis-ci builds show &quot;Killed&quot; message.  See (&lt;a href=&quot;https://travis-ci.org/apache/commons-lang/builds/96652842&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://travis-ci.org/apache/commons-lang/builds/96652842&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Using a github fork, I was able to get the code to pass if I re-ran tests multiple times.  I walked back several commits and was able to get similar Killed message going back three more commits.  (See &lt;a href=&quot;https://travis-ci.org/chonton/commons-lang/builds&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://travis-ci.org/chonton/commons-lang/builds&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The killed test is one of:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.StringEscapeUtilsTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.HashSetvBitSetTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ToStringStyleConcurrencyTest&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat_ParserTest&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15071724" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Fri, 25 Dec 2015 20:50:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;commit afc942c7b2bc0317cb549a3fd05080646e7274fc&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;reapply prior work after investigating Travis failures.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1191] Incorrect Javadoc StringUtils.containsAny(CharSequence, CharSequence...) </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1191</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Javadoc for boolean org.apache.commons.lang3.StringUtils.containsAny(CharSequence cs, CharSequence... searchCharSequences) says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;abcd&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;cd&quot;) = false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which is not true. It should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;abcd&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;cd&quot;) = true&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12920051">LANG-1191</key>
            <summary>Incorrect Javadoc StringUtils.containsAny(CharSequence, CharSequence...) </summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="qed">qed</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 8 Dec 2015 11:56:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:04 +0000</updated>

                            <comment id="15048715" author="yasar.siddiqui" created="Wed, 9 Dec 2015 14:10:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has been fixed in the javadoc&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="15116657" author="brentworden" created="Tue, 26 Jan 2016 04:25:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There does appear to be an inconsistency with:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1190] TypeUtils.isAssignable throws NullPointerException when fromType has type variables and toType generic superclass specifies type variable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1190</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang3.reflect.TypeUtils.*;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.lang.reflect.Type;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.ArrayList;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;Demonstration {

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;U&amp;gt; Iterable&amp;lt;U&amp;gt; someMethod() { &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;; }
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;WorkingClass &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; ArrayList { }
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;FailingClass &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; ArrayList&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; { }
    
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; NoSuchMethodException, SecurityException, IllegalAccessException, IllegalArgumentException, InvocationTargetException {
        Type fromType = Demonstration.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getDeclaredMethod(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;someMethod&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).getGenericReturnType();
        Type workingToType = wildcardType().withLowerBounds(WorkingClass.class).build();
        Type failingToType = wildcardType().withLowerBounds(FailingClass.class).build();
        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(fromType);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(workingToType);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(failingToType);
        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(isAssignable(fromType, workingToType));
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(isAssignable(fromType, failingToType));
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12919821">LANG-1190</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1188] StringUtils#join(T...): warning: [unchecked] Possible heap pollution from parameterized vararg type T</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1188</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;commons-lang3-3.4-src/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java:3302: warning: &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;unchecked&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Possible heap pollution from parameterized vararg type T&lt;br/&gt;
    public static &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; String join(final T... elements) {&lt;br/&gt;
                                             ^&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;usage: String.join(&quot; &quot;, stringarray)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;javac 1.8.0_25&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12916435">LANG-1188</key>
            <summary>StringUtils#join(T...): warning: [unchecked] Possible heap pollution from parameterized vararg type T</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                            <comment id="15312096" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 2 Jun 2016 10:21:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We could start adding comments to state why the warning is not a problem (if indeed that is the case).&lt;br/&gt;
This means analysing the true cause of the warning, which will have to be done at some point anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This would at least indicate to developers/maintainers/3rd parties that the warning has been taken into acount.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s obviously important not to suppress the warning without first ensuring that the code is safe.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15568178" author="kinow" created="Wed, 12 Oct 2016 09:26:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;+1 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; for adding comments now in the code. <item>
            <title>[LANG-1187] Method createNumber from NumberUtils doesn&apos;t work for floating point numbers other than Float</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1187</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;demo:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; Number n = org.apache.commons.lang3.math.NumberUtils.createNumber(&quot;6264583.33&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(&quot;lang3_createNumber_6264583.33----&amp;gt;&quot; + n);&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;while n will be 6264583.5. not 6264583.33&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12915772">LANG-1187</key>
            <summary>Method createNumber from NumberUtils doesn&apos;t work for floating point numbers other than Float</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="leizhiyuan">leizhiyuan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 24 Nov 2015 12:06:49 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 12 Jun 2016 11:31:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 12 Jun 2016 08:27:24 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                                    <component>lang.math.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15024532" author="rikles" created="Tue, 24 Nov 2015 13:42:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I just take a quick look and it&apos;s seem to be caused by the order of conversion priority for decimal number (Float &amp;gt; Double &amp;gt; BigDecimal) and the test for select between those types is based on the number of digits past the decimal point.&lt;br/&gt;
But wouldn&apos;t it be on significant digits instead ? (if significant digits &amp;gt;=7 there is a risk that float can be unable to represents the entire number)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15326385" author="pascalschumacher" created="Sun, 12 Jun 2016 11:31:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1018&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils.createNumber(final String str)  Precision will be lost&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1018&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1018&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; also solves this, so this will be fixed in 3.5.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1186] NullPointerException in FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1186</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Java 8u60 has a change where &lt;tt&gt;DateFormatSymbols.getZoneStrings&lt;/tt&gt; returns arrays with 7 elements instead of 5 like it previously had. For some locales, the additional two elements are null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Running org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest
Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.597 sec &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; FAILURE! - in org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest
testTimeZoneStrategyPattern(org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest)  Time elapsed: 0.597 sec  &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; ERROR!
java.lang.NullPointerException: &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:856)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.getLocaleSpecificStrategy(FastDateParser.java:647)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.getStrategy(FastDateParser.java:616)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.access$100(FastDateParser.java:74)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$StrategyParser.letterPattern(FastDateParser.java:230)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$StrategyParser.getNextStrategy(FastDateParser.java:214)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.init(FastDateParser.java:161)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:147)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:108)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest.testTimeZoneStrategyPattern(FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest.java:31)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12914741">LANG-1186</key>
            <summary>NullPointerException in FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nmanley">Nick Manley</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 20 Nov 2015 05:34:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Nov 2016 20:42:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 18 Dec 2015 01:34:53 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15015251" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 20 Nov 2015 05:34:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user NickManley opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/117&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/117&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1186&quot; title=&quot;NullPointerException in FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1186&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1186&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Fix NullPointerException in FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Java 8u60 has a change where `DateFormatSymbols.getZoneStrings` returns arrays with 7 elements instead of 5 like it previously had. For some locales, the additional two elements are null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Example from the unit tests:&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;br/&gt;
    Running org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest&lt;br/&gt;
    Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.597 sec &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; FAILURE! - in org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest&lt;br/&gt;
    testTimeZoneStrategyPattern(org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest)  Time elapsed: 0.597 sec  &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; ERROR!&lt;br/&gt;
    java.lang.NullPointerException: null&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$TimeZoneStrategy.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:856)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.getLocaleSpecificStrategy(FastDateParser.java:647)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.getStrategy(FastDateParser.java:616)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.access$100(FastDateParser.java:74)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$StrategyParser.letterPattern(FastDateParser.java:230)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser$StrategyParser.getNextStrategy(FastDateParser.java:214)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.init(FastDateParser.java:161)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:147)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FastDateParser.java:108)&lt;br/&gt;
    	at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest.testTimeZoneStrategyPattern(FastDateParser_TimeZoneStrategyTest.java:31)&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/NickManley/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/NickManley/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; master&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/117.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/117.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #117&lt;/p&gt;

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-1184] StringUtils#normalizeSpace no longer normalizes unicode non-breaking spaces (\u00A0)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This works with 3.3.2, but fails with 3.4&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;a b&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, StringUtils.normalizeSpace(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;a\u00A0 b&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12910480">LANG-1184</key>
            <summary>StringUtils#normalizeSpace no longer normalizes unicode non-breaking spaces (\u00A0)</summary>

                            <comment id="14994320" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 6 Nov 2015 19:45:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user PascalSchumacher opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils#normalizeSpace no longer normalizes unicode non-breaking spaces (\u00A0)&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1184&quot;&gt;LANG-1184&lt;/a&gt;: StringUtils#normalizeSpace no longer normalizes unicode no&#8230;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &#8230;n-breaking spaces (\u00A0) and does not trim control chars at the end anymore&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="15103573" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 04:26:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user hen commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172290723&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172290723&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="15103582" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 04:42:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user garydgregory commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172291572&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172291572&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Thank you for your interest in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Java says a non-breaking whitespace is not a whitespace:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ```java&lt;br/&gt;
    Character.isWhitespace(&apos;\u00A0&apos;));&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    returns `false`.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    So I am not sure this patch is valid.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="15103620" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 06:51:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user hen commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172296208&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172296208&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Given one of the behaviours of nbsp is not to collapse down, there is a logic in normalizeWhitespace not normalizing the nbsp characters. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15103797" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 17:23:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172354689&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172354689&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    @garydgregory @hen Thanks for the reviews. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    As mentioned in the jira issue the goal of this pull request is not to add anything, but to restore pre-3.4 functionality: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    These work with 3.3.2, but fail with 3.4:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ```java&lt;br/&gt;
    assertEquals(&quot;a b&quot;, StringUtils.normalizeSpace(&quot;a\u00A0 b&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
    assertEquals(&quot;b&quot;, StringUtils.normalizeSpace(&quot;b\u0000&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    while keeping in place most of the performance improvement added in &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/commit/bc8e23808b9d8d0c9b67270ef35d04ebd9d89cc8&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/commit/bc8e23808b9d8d0c9b67270ef35d04ebd9d89cc8&lt;/a&gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I used same tests &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/librucha/commons-lang-normalizespaces-benchmark&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/librucha/commons-lang-normalizespaces-benchmark&lt;/a&gt; and there is only a 10% performance regression for the restored pre-3.4 behavior (the trimming of the string and the normalization of non-braking spaces). &lt;/p&gt;


</comment>
                            <comment id="15103805" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 17:39:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172357021&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172357021&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    @hen  Thanks again for the in-depth review.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Part of the is `isEmpty()` is necessary, because `normalizeSpace` has to return `null` for `null` parameters according to javadoc `@return the modified string with whitespace normalized, &lt;/p&gt;
{@code null}
&lt;p&gt; if null String input`&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I have updated the pull request and replaced the is `isEmpty()` check by `str == null`.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I have also updated javadoc to reflect that non-breaking space is normalized.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15103886" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 17 Jan 2016 19:37:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user garydgregory commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172369835&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-172369835&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Hi All,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I&apos;m more concerned about what the proper behavior of the method is, rather than its behavior in some past arbitrary version. Since Java does not define a nbsp as a whitespace, it should not be normalized away IMO. Now, if you want it normalized, we could talk about adding another method or documenting how to deal with this special use case. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Are there other characters that are ws-like characters that return false for Character.isWhitespace(). Unicode is pretty rich, maybe there is more. What would this new method be called?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15118036" author="githubbot" created="Tue, 26 Jan 2016 21:10:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-175231559&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-175231559&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Hi Gary,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    3.0 had the same behavior as 3.3.2, but I guess this is not a productive discussion.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I know that `Character.isWhitespace` defines `\u00A0` as not a white space, but for example guava &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/google/guava/blob/8fbeb9038cbe8b382b1ee188ae8459203cd04fb5/guava/src/com/google/common/base/CharMatcher.java#L1217&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/google/guava/blob/8fbeb9038cbe8b382b1ee188ae8459203cd04fb5/guava/src/com/google/common/base/CharMatcher.java#L1217&lt;/a&gt; classifies it as whitespace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    If you want to keep the changed behavior I suggest at least to re-add the `trim()` call or to remove the `Additionally &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;
{@link #trim(String)}
&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; removes control characters (char &amp;lt;= 32) from both ends of this String.` part of the java doc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I&apos;m not unicode expert, but &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-breaking_space&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-breaking_space&lt;/a&gt; has a list of some more non-breaking-space unicode characters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    As for the method name I guess the easy way out would be to add a flag to normalize space. I can not come up with a good method name at the moment `normalizeAllSpace`, is my best try.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15255510" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 24 Apr 2016 06:11:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-213900174&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-213900174&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Hi all,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    an comments?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15275656" author="pascalschumacher" created="Sun, 8 May 2016 18:22:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I the &quot;non-trimming&quot; part of the issue and created an new issue for it &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1226&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1226&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15275657" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 8 May 2016 18:25:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user garydgregory commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-217737900&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113#issuecomment-217737900&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Yes, let&apos;s add a new method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15481824" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 11 Sep 2016 14:20:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher commented on the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/184&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/184&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    @phoenix384 The problem is that starting with 3.4 StringUtils#normalizeSpace no longer normalizes unicode non-breaking spaces. I reported this as a bug and argued for reverting this behavior, but other people disagreed. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    For details see:&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1184&lt;/a&gt; &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15501369" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 18 Sep 2016 17:55:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user PascalSchumacher closed the pull request at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/113&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                                        <issuelink>
            <issuekey id="12837413">LANG-1148</issuekey>
        </issuelink>

                            <issuelinktype id="12310050">
                    <name>Regression</name>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1182] Clarify JavaDoc of StringUtils.containsAny()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1182</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;(1) The javadoc for StringUtils.containsAny(CharSequence cs, CharSequence... searchCharSequences) confusingly says &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;abcd&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;cd&quot;) = false&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;You can verify this actually returns true by running this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (!StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;abcd&quot;, &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;cd&quot;)) &lt;br/&gt;
            throw new AssertionError(&quot;Third sample from StringUtils 3.4 javadoc&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(2) The javadoc for containsAny(final CharSequence cs, final CharSequence searchChars) is inadequate, and could easily mislead naive readers to believe this containsAny() looks for a matching sequence (substring) rather than characters in a set:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;zzabyycdxx&quot;, &quot;za&quot;) = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;zzabyycdxx&quot;, &quot;by&quot;) = true&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;In other words, both examples would be equally true for StringUtils.contains().  I suggest adding clarifying examples, like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;zzabyycdxx&quot;, &quot;\tx&quot;) = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;StringUtils.containsAny(&quot;zzabyycdxx&quot;, &quot;$.#yF&quot;) = true&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;

</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12909364">LANG-1182</key>
            <summary>Clarify JavaDoc of StringUtils.containsAny()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="larry_west">Larry West</reporter>
                        <labels>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1180] StringEscapeUtils.escapeEcmaScript incorrectly handles single-quotes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1180</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following code illustrates the problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;public void testEscapes() {
    String ecmaSingleEscape = StringEscapeUtils.escapeEcmaScript(&quot;X&apos;Y&quot;);
    String ecmaDoubleEscape = StringEscapeUtils.escapeEcmaScript(&quot;X\&quot;Y&quot;);

    assertEquals(&quot;X\\\&quot;Y&quot;, ecmaDoubleEscape); // works correctly
    assertEquals(&quot;X&apos;Y&quot;, ecmaSingleEscape); // incorrectly inserts a backslash
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to json.org, single-quote is not a valid character for being backslash-escaped in a string. The only valid backslash escapes are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;\&quot;
&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;
\/&lt;br/&gt;
\b&lt;br/&gt;
\f&lt;br/&gt;
\n&lt;br/&gt;
\r&lt;br/&gt;
\t&lt;br/&gt;
\u four-hex-digits&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Digging deeper, it seems that this is a difference between JSON (single-quote must not be escaped, since strings can only be delimited with double-quotes) and JavaScript (single-quote can be escaped because strings can also be delimited with single-quotes). This suggests that you really want two different versions of escapeEcmaScript &amp;#8211; one focused on JSON and the other focuses on the broader JavaScript language.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12908681">LANG-1180</key>
            <summary>StringEscapeUtils.escapeEcmaScript incorrectly handles single-quotes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
